editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE COQUETTE; OR, THE MISTAKES of the HEART.
[Price One Shilling and Six-pence.]
THE COQUETTE; OR, THE MISTAKES of the HEART: A COMEDY. As performed at the THEATRES-ROYAL IN YORK and HULL.
BATH: PRINTED BY R. CRUTTWELL.
MDCCLXXVII.
SCENE, LONDON.
TIME, that of Repreſentation.

div.head: TO Mrs. NEWTON, OF KING's-BROMLEY, STAFFORDSHIRE.
div.p: WITH the greateſt reſpect, I beg leave to lay the following ſcenes at your feet—My ſole aim in writing them, was to blend Inſtruction with Amuſement.
TRULY ſenſible that Example operates much more powerfully than Precept, forgive my vanity in pointing out ſo perfect a character as your's for imitation.
WHERE Youth, Beauty, and Virtue unite to—Your delicacy has ſnatched the pen from my unwilling hand—I muſt obey—Suffer me only to add, that I am, MADAM,

closer.signed: With the greateſt truth, Your moſt obedient Very humble ſervant, The AUTHOR.

div.p: THE moment that a Reader takes up a Book with a Deſign to peruſe it, he naturally wiſhes for all the Information poſſible, relative to the Writer and Writing of it—
WILLING, in every reaſonable Degree, to ſatisfy the Curioſity of my good Friends and Purchaſers, I ſhall candidly anſwer their following Queſtions:
Pray, who is the Author of this Comedy?

p.hi: A man in Obſcurity, unnoticed, and content to remain ſo.

div.p: Has it ever been performed in London?
Was it ever offered to the Managers of either Theatre there?
For what reaſon?

p.hi: Becauſe the Author was truly ſenſible that it had not Merit ſufficient to recommend it to their Notice.

div.p: What are his Motives for publiſhing it now?
Is it worth purchaſing?

p.hi: An odd Queſtion—He is afraid not—But, good bye, Read on and judge for yourſelf.

div.p: The following Names came too late to be inſerted in their proper place.

div.head: THE COQUETTE; OR, THE MISTAKES of the HEART.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: SO, Sedley, you really have been three weeks without ſeeing Miſs Bloomer?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: True, I aſſure you, Woodford, and intend, if my reſolution holds, never to ſee her again.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: But I underſtood every thing was ſettled between you both, and that nothing remain'd but to name the happy day.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Prithee, Woodford, no more.—It adds to my uneaſineſs to hear her mention'd.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Becauſe I find, this too ſuſceptible heart of mine cannot ſo readily eraſe the impreſſions her youth, beauty, and innocence have made upon it.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Indeed! But what reaſon can you have for wiſhing it?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: The greateſt in the world, Woodford.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I cannot think ſo,—explain, or I ſhall certainly imagine you whimſical and capricious.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p:
When I firſt paid my addreſſes to Miſs Bloomer, ſuch were the beauties of her mind as well
as perſon, that I fancied I had found one, all perfect as the firſt, before ſhe fell.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Then were you in an Adamitical paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: A fool's one, rather,—ſhe received me with ſuch a flattering diſtinction that I thought myſelf the happieſt of mortals, when unluckily, her guardian's dying put her into the immediate poſſeſſion of a large fortune.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Now I ſhould have thought that the luckieſt circumſtance that cou'd have happen'd.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Quite the contrary,—thus freed from reſtraint, at the age of eighteen, ſhe emerged into all the faſhionable follies of the great world, without a real friend to adviſe, or direct her.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Why did not you undertake that office?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: I did, but ſoon found it was an ungrateful one—ſo fine a girl, independent of intereſted motives, cou'd not fail of attracting a crowd of admirers; and—

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: You, naturally grew jealous.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Jealous! My heart was torn in pieces.—'Twas then I diſcover'd a levity of temper, a thoughtleſſneſs, a love of pleaſure, that deſtroy'd my hopes.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Pſha! trifles.—Foibles like theſe are as ſpecks upon the ſun.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Ay, but in time they threaten a total eclipſe.—No character, however contemptible, but was encouraged as a lover.—No ſcene of gaiety, however cenſurable, but was purſued with avidity.—A thouſand inſtances did I patiently bear with, in hopes of amendment.—Oft in the gentleſt terms, did I convey advice, and repreſent the hazards ſhe ran; as oft was I forbad her preſence.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! upon my word, you took an excellent method of rendering yourſelf agreeable to a girl of her age and ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p:
But when I intended that girl as a partner for life, cou'd you blame my cautious conduct? No,
Woodford; though never man was more ſenſible of beauty's charms than I, yet unleſs thoſe charms are adorned with virtue, they make not half the impreſſion.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: That's a little romantic; but pray go on.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Many times did I reſcue her from the moſt imminent dangers which her indiſcretions plunged her into, yet ſtill ſhe perſevered.—At length,—

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Hold, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis Monſieur Fineſſe,—one of my rivals,—a fellow, whoſe impudence can only be equall'd by his ignorance.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ah, gentlement!—Votre tres humble ſerviteur!—I be moſt glad to ſee you both,—Monſieur Sedley, I beg a to ſpeak von word or two wid you.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Any thing particular, Fineſſe?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, oui, ver particular—for your own ear.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: You may ſpeak out before Woodford, I have juſt been acquainting him with the whole affair.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Qu' avez vous fair?—Ma foy, dat be wrong done.—You ſhou'd ſay noting to hurt de fine Lady's reputation.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: He is my particular friend, and I can anſwer for his diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Parbleu! particular friend ſometime do de moſht miſchief.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: That will not be the caſe with me, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Come, what news of Miſs Bloomer?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ah, pauvre Lady! ſhe had de grand eſcape yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Eſcape? how?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Why, ſhe be taking de innocent diverſion at Vauxhall, wid de bon companie, as ſhe ſuppoſe, and engage in de partie wid tree gentlemen, and deux ladie, to be entertain in a boat on de Thames.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: In a boat on the Thames?—Well!—Go on.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Dey be all ſtranger to her, but vat of dat? She not tink any harm.—So dey row, row along, have de muſique, ſing de petite chanſon, and be all ſo merry and gay, till dey land at de Couſin, as dey call her, but begar ſhe be—Vat you call Fille de joie?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Woman of the town.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui,—ſhe be woman of de town,—den Miſs Bloomer find her miſtake, and vant to return home again.—Dey ſay, no, no, and grow hardis,—at laſt, when ſhe be almoſt excedée, etrois gentlemen by accident hear her cries, and tout à fait, reſcue her.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Wou'd I had been there!—Villains!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, oui!—Villains indeed.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: You ſee, Woodford, there's another inſtance of her conduct.—Do you think it poſſible for me to be happy with ſuch a woman?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I tell you, man, you are too delicate.—Tho' appearances are againſt her, yet, I dare affirm, that theſe are all miſtakes of the heart, which in time her better judgment will rectify.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: True, dey be all in de heart,—all vivacité, noting elſe.—I muſt find ſome oder opportunity, when I ſhall have him to himſelf. (aſide) Well, Monſieur Sedley, I vill bid you de good morn,—I am going to viſit de Lady, I ſhall hear ſometing more dere, and den I vill call on you at home, in private.—Gentlemen, ſans compliment, I have de honneur to be your very humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Hearky', Sedley, do you build anything upon this fellow's intelligence?—A wretch! that's an outcaſt, and diſgrace to his nation.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Yet this very outcaſt, as he really is, does ſhe treat in the moſt encouraging manner; and, without the leaſt enquiry into his fortune or character, admit amongſt the number of her admirers.—But let us change the ſubject.—So then it ſeems your Uncle has civilly diſmiſs'd you his houſe?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Not ſo civilly, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Don't you think you deſerved it? Captain Helm, you know, has ſpent the greater part of his life in ploughing the tempeſtuous ocean, and tho' poſſeſt of an excellent heart, has not the leaſt idea of the refined ſentiments inſpired by a liberal education.—You were certain that your whole dependance was upon him, yet refus'd flattering the harmleſs foibles which peculiarly mark his character.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: You miſtake me, Sedley, I often did, till this laſt affair.—But, when he commenc'd my rival, my happineſs was too much concern'd to trifle any longer.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Well, and has he declar'd his paſſion?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: No, but as a preparatory ſtep, he has given Lady Younglove (who is juſt return'd to town with her daughter) to underſtand, that for the future, ſhe muſt not encourage my pretenſions, as I have nothing to expect from him.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: So! your hopes are all over in that quarter?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Entirely! I called yeſterday, to welcome my dear girl, my beauteous Flora, to London, and was refuſed admittance.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: True, and I am now reduced to ſuch diſtreſs, that, unleſs you can aſſiſt me with your advice, and—

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Here's my hand,—Depend upon my utmoſt, I feel too much myſelf, tho' from a different cauſe, not to compaſſionate you.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I expected no leſs from your generous friendſhip, but how ſhall we act?—What can I do?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Upon my word, I don't know.—I own yours is a critical caſe.—But, we muſt not deſpair,—I believe as matters ſtand, we had beſt work by ſtratagem. Luckily, I ſtand high in the eſtimation of your Uncle, as well as Lady Younglove.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: You'll find him inexorable, and her—

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Not proof againſt flattery,—all mankind have their weak ſide, Woodford, and much may be done by taking a proper advantage of their follies.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I wiſh you may not be miſtaken in the preſent caſe.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Never fear.—Let me ſee, (Panſes) No, that won't do.—Stay, I believe I have it.—Suppoſe, I attack Lady Younglove myſelf, and perſuade her, that I am dying for love of her.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: No, no, that's impoſſible,—'twould be too ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I'll lay my life there's nothing eaſier.—Attack Widows by ſtorm, and they can't reſiſt you.—Beſides, her time grows ſhort, and as ſhe was in ſuch a violent hurry to get a ſecond huſband, there's all the reaſon in the world to imagine her ſtill more impatient for a third.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: But what end do you propoſe by this ſcheme?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: To ſerve you, but in what manner I have not yet determined.—Come, let's home to my houſe and conſider farther.—Nay, nay, no excuſes.—I ſee you are unfit to be left to yourſelf.—And the heart which does not feel the diſtreſs of a friend, is not worthy of exiſtence.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—And ſo, Monſieur Sedley believe all de Menſonge, all de ſtory you tell him of my Lady.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui, he tink it all verité.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Bon!—And I ſo ſpeak in your praiſe, dat ſhe love you more dan all her oder admirers.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Brave, ma petite mignonne!—And, ſhe be aſſurée, dat I be von man of grand qualite?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Sans doubt!—ſhe no ſuſpect any ting—But, you remember—If I help you to marry de Lady, I am to have de five hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh!—Faites fond ſur moi—Depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Vera well—Je ſuis content!—I am ſatisfied,—She be now alone, ſtay you dere, and I vil ſay you are waiting for her.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Allons, Mademoiſelle.—Begar! I vil put de von little ſheat upon you too, for all dat.—Love own country vera well, but love own ſelf muſh better.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Ha! my dear Monſieur Fineſſe—I am extravagantly glad to ſee you.—I wiſh he was at the Devil with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: You make me quite happy.—If your neck was broke.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: What, I find you ſtill dance attendance at Miſs Bloomer's levee.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Il eſt vrai, Monſieur Ogle—It is true,—When a young Lady like Miſs Bloomer diſtinguiſh de gentilhomme, de gentilhomme do all in his power to return de compliment.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: You are right, Monſieur,—Juſt my caſe to a hair.—If a fooliſh girl takes it into her head, to fall deſperately in love with me,—tho' upon my ſoul, I can't ſee for what—Can I be ſo barbarous as to ſlight her?—Oh, no, 'tis not in my nature to be ſo inhuman. [Miſs Bloomer ſings without.] Hark!—Here ſhe comes, and as lively as ever.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your moſt obedient,—Hey day! Only you two!—Why I am quite deſerted this morning.—Oh, Mr. Spangle! what not drowned yet?—Pſha! you are not half the deſpairing lover you ought to be.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, fie for ſhame, Monſieur Spangle, not drown yourſelf to pleaſe de Lady.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—I dare ſay, Monſieur Fineſſe, you'd readily oblige me with ſuch a proof of your gallantry, and reſpect.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, madam, I beg to be excuſe—De hang, and de drown'd be ſo barbare, ſo truly Englis, dat it ſhock a me quite—No, rader let me live to adore you, ma belle ange.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Then is there no poſſibility of inſpiring that obdurate boſom of yours?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Oh! I am in love!

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Yes, violently, to diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: And may I aſk, who is the happy object of your paſſion?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: The monkey you gave me—He is ſo much the image of yourſelf, that I have doted on him this week paſt.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! De monkey—Ha! ha! ha! le drole, ſerviteur, Monſieur Monkey.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I aſſure you I intend to dreſs the dear creature up in a faſhionable ſuit, have him frizz'd, powder'd, and painted alamode, and have not the leaſt doubt but he'll acquit himſelf as well as moſt of the fine gentlemen about town.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: You know the power you have over me, and love to tyrannize.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Poor gentleman!—how pathetically that was ſpoken! Pray go on.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: I aſſure you, madam, little as you may think of—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: That pretty, delicate, enamell'd face of yours; yet, it has made many a Lady's heart go pit-a-pat.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Admirable!—Ha! ha! ha!—Ah! pauvre diable, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: As for Monſieur Fineſſe here, there is not the leaſt fear of the weather's injuring his complexion.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: No, madam, mine be de true bronze.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p:
Well, gentlemen, I ſuppoſe you are both come upon the old ſubject—To ſhew how impartial
partial I am, both ſhall have fair play, and each declare his paſſion in turn. You, Mr. Spangle, being my humble ſervant the longeſt, ſhall begin firſt.—Come, make haſte, you have no time to loſe—I expect twenty more, every moment, on the ſame errand.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Hearky', you ſoft bewitching little gypſy.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Bravo! go on.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Do you think I am always to be treated in this unmerciful manner?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.l: With mercy treat your humble ſlave,
And as your you're beautiful be brave.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Curſe catch me! if I am not reveng'd on you for this cruelty.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: What, you'll break my chain?—Do, if you can—If my glaſs is to be believ'd, that's out of your power.—Well, ſince I find you have nothing more to ſay, now, to you—"Tho' laſt not leaſt in my eſteem."

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Den, madam, ſans compliment, ou flatterie, you be de ſweeteſt and moſt lovely creature I ever ſaw—And if I be ſo happy as to—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Have it in your power to make me unhappy—

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O, permettez moi, madam, you not hear me out.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mrs. Faſhion, your Ladyſhip's milliner, to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Shew her up.—I am very ſorry, gentlemen, to be deprived of the pleaſure of your company, but buſineſs you know—

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: O, dear ma'am, no excuſe—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to ſee you again, this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Je m'en vais, madam, I ſhall be here when you no tink.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Hold, come back—I've a thought which may be of infinite ſervice to you and me.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Pray, madam,—Que dites vous? Vat you ſay?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Why, as you are both rivals, and men of ſuch undoubted courage, what think you of a rencontre to-morrow morning?

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: O, dear ma'am, we are infinitely oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui, too much oblige, indeed, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I wou'd not propoſe this to every hotheaded ſpark, but I have ſuch a reliance upon your prudence and diſcretion, that I am not the leaſt apprehenſive of ill conſequences.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: You pay us a great compliment, really, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: No more than you deſerve,—By this, you'll acquire a reputation in the world, and add to my fame.—Go, go, and let me hear that you have done ſomething to be talk'd of before I ſee you again.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Madam, I ſhall have de glory of obeying your commands.—Monſieur Spangle, ſince noting elſe will ſatisfy de lady, I beg you to witdraw, and let me have de honneur to cut your troat a la Françoiſe.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: O, I'll withdraw with all my heart.—But, the Devil fetch me, if I have my throat cut, a la Françoiſe, or a la Anglois.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! thus do I ſport with fools.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Well, Mrs. Faſhion, ſure ſomething very particular brings you here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Very particular indeed, your Ladyſhip,—And yet, it is not particular to you neither, for, heaven bleſs you! it happens every day.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Well, what is it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Ah, that ſweet ſace!—No wonder it turns every body's brain.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: What is all this about?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: I aſſure you, I have ſo much work in hand, that I could hardly ſpare the time to—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I wiſh you would waſte a little leſs of it now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Some of my beſt cuſtomers too.—I ſhall be oblig'd to ſit up all night.—But poor gentleman, he is in ſuch a bitter taking—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: What gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Ah! that ſweet ſhape and air.—Well, if it be your lot to come together, you'll make a lovely couple.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Was ever any thing ſo provoking!—I proteſt, I ſhall be quite angry, if you keep me any longer in ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Angry! no, no, that face of yours was never made for frowning.—What ſay you to a new admirer, now?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Pſha! was this the mighty matter,—I don't want admirers, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: No, by my faith, don't you, but this is one out of the common road.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Then, he had better turn into the common road again, or he may chance to go aſtray.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Ah! you are always witty.—Oh, he is one of the clevereſt, propereſt, beſt-bred gentlemen,—I'm ſure he brings tears into my eyes, to hear all the fine things he ſays of you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: You are very tender, indeed, Mrs. Faſhion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: As a chicken.—And then for quality, he tops them all.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Does he?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p:
Oh, yes, Miſs—You muſt know that his father's a Lord, he is the eldeſt ſon, but upon ſome little diſagreement—A love affair—A Lady of
vaſt fortune his father wanted him to marry.—He took lodgings in my houſe, in order to be private, till matters are made up.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Then he is your lodger at preſent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: And the beſt lodger I ever had—Money is no more to him than pins are to me.—Then for company, my houſe is hardly ever empty of Lords, Dukes, and Baronets.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Oh! he lives quite private, I find.—But, pray, what may be the name of this extraordinary perſon?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Why that's a ſecret—But between ourſelves, I have found out from his ſervants, that he is the young Lord Flamwell.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Flamwell!—I never heard of the name before—But that's no wonder, for of late, nobility ſpring up like muſhrooms.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: He has ſeen you at ſome of the public places, and has been dying for you ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: So, you are come Embaſſadreſs from him?

sp.speaker: Mrs Faſh.
sp.p: Me, Miſs!—Lord, what could put ſuch a thing into your head?—He does not even know that I ever ſaw you—And yet, he is in ſuch diſtreſs, that if you would condeſcend to come to my houſe this afternoon—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: To your houſe?—Surely, Mrs. Faſhion, you don't imagine, that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Nay, only for a quarter of an hour, or ſo, by way of amuſement.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I thank you, but I don't want amuſement.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: But, I have ſome of neweſt faſhions come over from Paris—Not a creature in London has ſeen them, but myſelf—O, they'd become your Ladyſhip admirably—So elegant, ſo pretty—If you chuſe, you may have the honour of leading the taſte for the next three months.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Faſhion, you are very good.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Ay, I thought I ſhou'd pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Then, I'll order my chair, and give you a call before dinner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: I never ſaw any thing in my life ſo becoming.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Be ſure, you don't let them be ſeen by any body before I come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Seen! no, not if a Dutcheſs was to bribe me.—Then, I'll expect your Ladyſhip.—Lord, what time I have ſpent, prattle, prattle, never think, and yet, ſo much work!—Hurry, hurry, not a minute to loſe—Your Ladyſhip's moſt obedient, humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: This intelligence has given me new ſpirits—I proteſt, I began to be apprehenſive that my charms were on the fade—A whole week paſſed, and not one new admirer.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: My dear Belgrove, you are come moſt opportunely—Do you know, that ſince I ſaw you laſt, I have made a freſh conqueſt?

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: I don't find any thing ſo ſurprizing in that.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Why no, that's true, but I have now roſe a ſtep higher, and captivated a Lord.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Lord, or commoner, I ſuppoſe he'll ſhare the ſame fate with the reſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Certainly, my dear, you would not have me be unjuſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: No, really, I would not, therefore entirely diſapprove of your making ſuch fools of them.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: You miſtake, child, the generality of them were fools ready made to my hand.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Some of them might be ſo, but I don't find you are in the leaſt more favourable to men of ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Oh! I hate your ſenſible men, and take a particular pleaſure in tormenting them.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: That's very extraordinary.—But why ſo?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Becauſe it adds more to my reputation, to lead in chains one of thoſe wiſe Lords of the creation, who has ſenſe enough to know I uſe him ill, yet not power ſufficient to break his fetters, than a thouſand of thoſe mincing, whiffling, trifling, good-for-nothing, pretty, Maſter Jeſſamys.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Well! tho' I ſhall never approve of your ſcheme, I almoſt wiſh for your ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Spirits, my dear!—Lord, what ſhould put me out of ſpirits?—Time enough for me to pine and languiſh, when the Hey-day of my charms are over—Mine, I'm afraid, will be but a ſhort reign, ſo am determin'd to make the moſt of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Then I find you do intend to marry.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ſome time or other.—. It wou'd mortify me prodigiouſly, to die an old maid.—No, no, I aſſure you, I have not the leaſt ambition to lead apes, no more than I have at preſent to be led by one myſelf.—I wou'd only play with the male creatures, as a ſkilful angler does with his fiſh.—Amuſe myſelf the ſportive ſummer's day, bait my hook well for gudgeons, ſee the pretty innocents, nibble, nibble, nibble, as faſt as I could caſt in—Draw them out when I pleaſed—Stroke the delicate things, and then throw them in again—till evening ſun having diſagreeably lengthen'd my ſhadow, pick out the hero of the ſtream, and retire to my ruſtic cottage, content with the pleaſures of the day.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: But, pray, in the midſt of this round of amuſements, do you never feel a pang for the loſs of Sedley?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: If I really thought I had loſt him for ever, I ſhould be heartily mortified.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Don't you think it begins to look like it?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Why, I am a little alarmed,—for to confeſs the truth ſincerely, which in thoſe caſes I very ſeldom do—Of all the men that ever addreſs'd me, he is the only one who has made an impreſtion on my heart.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Why did not you uſe him better?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: 'Tis not in my nature to be ſerious long together, therefore why ſhould he expect it?

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Conſider the many obligations you are under to him.—The many dangers he reſcued you from, which your innocent levity expoſed you to.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: That's true; but then he ſhould not have taken ſo ungenerous an advantage of them, as to tell me, that I did wrong, and preſcribe rules for my future conduct.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Were not thoſe rules for your good?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Yes, but we are not always diſpos'd to reliſh advice.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: I really think, if you loſe him, you'll never meet with ſuch another.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: If I am diſappointed of him, I ſhall never have any other, that's paſt a doubt—And as a proof, were he now to return, I would frankly own, that, though I am innocent, even in intention of acting wrong, yet, my thoughtleſſneſs, many times, leads me into great errors, which nothing but the ſincerity of my heart can excuſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: 'Tis great pity you did not make this declaration before.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Pſha! he muſt take me, as he finds me.—Can he be ſo unconſcionable as to expect, that I ſhould draw up my head, hold down my eyes, put my hands together, drop him a low curteſy, and ſay,—I have been a naughty girl to be ſure, but, pray forgive me this time, and indeed, and double deed, I'll do ſo no more?

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p:
No, but he might reaſonably expect, that you'd diſmiſs your numerous train of followers;
—and, as you have often ſacrificed men of worth at the ſhrine of folly, ſo in return, to make a general oblation—Offer up a hecatomb of fools, at the altar of diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Do I bid the creatures follow me?

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Nor don't you encourage them, when they do?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Ay, that is, becauſe I hate ill-nature.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: But are not you afraid your reputation ſhould ſuffer?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Oh, my dear, not in the leaſt—Every thing we do becomes us,—Our very frailties are pleaſing.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Conſider, the—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Poſitively, I won't conſider about the matter—So, come along, and always remember theſe never-failing lines—

q.l: If to her ſhare, ſome female errors fall,
Look on her face, and you'll forget them all.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: CAPTAIN HELM diſcover'd lying on a Couch, SWAB waiting.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: SWAB!

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Here, your Honour.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: What ſort of weather abroad?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: A little hazey, your Honour; the wind S. S-E.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: D'ye think you cou'd take me under convoy as far as Lady Younglove's?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I warrant I'll tow you along, if ſo be as how you'll keep above water.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Say you ſo?—Then on with your beſt jacket and trowſers, and help me to rig myſelf out.

div.p: Ha! Sedley!—What chear, boy?—How goes it?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Very well, I thank you, Captain.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Give me your hand—here, Swab, help to heave me up—ſo, ſo—now, turn out, and keep a ſtrict watch.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: If Bet Mainſail, my meſs-mate's widow, hails me again, what anſwer ſhall I give her?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Stow her hold well with right Nantz—Give her five guineas to buy new rigging, and tell her, if ſhe'll hoiſt the ſign of Admiral Boſeawen on Portſmouth Common, I'll take care to keep her off a lee ſhore.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Bleſs your Honour's glory!—She ſhall have as much of the good creature as ſhe can carry;—and, ſnatch my bowlings, if I don't tip her half a piece myſelf, for old acquaintance ſake.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: You ſee I am laid upon the ſtocks a little, but no matter for that—Tho' my out-works are ſomething damaged, yet my inſide is heart of oak.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it—Preſuming, Captain, on the regard you always profeſt for me, I am now come to intercede in behalf of your nephew.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Avaſt, avaſt, tack about, and pay away no more of that cable—My nephew, d'ye ſee, is a lazy land-lubber—If he had taken my advice, I would have made a man of him, and taught him to hand, reef, and ſteer, with e'er a ſeaman in the navy.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Theſe are accompliſhments, Captain, not ſuitable to every man's taſte and genius.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Then their taſte is not worth a rope's end—I myſelf, tho' a younger brother, made my own fortune while his father was ſquandering away his—I was twice round the globe, before I was forty—In every birth, from cabbin-boy, up to Captain of the Terrible—And now, having ſufficient to lie by, I am reſolved to enjoy it, and ride in a ſmooth harbour all the reſt of my days.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: But, Captain, tho' you was ſo fond of the ocean, and had ſuch ſucceſs, your nephew may not have the ſame inclinations, and you ſhould make ſome allowance.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No, that's not my way—So, if he has a mind to gain the wind of my affection, he muſt ſheer off from the little frigate he has ſo long kept in chace, and let me fit him out for a vovage in the Tempeſt, which ſails in a few weeks for the Eaſt-Indies.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Then your reſolution is fixed—

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: As the Poles.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And in his abſence, I ſuppoſe, you intend attacking Miſs Flora yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Right, I have ſome thoughts of bearing down that way.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: But, Captain, don't the great diſparity of years between you and her, deter you?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No, the more danger, the more honour—Mayhap, you may think it ſtrange, that after ſteering ſo long clear of a wife, I ſhould, all of a ſudden, veer about, and clap the matrimonial tack aboard.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: He that's long at ſea, will find the wind blow from every point of the compaſs—I have ſeldom been ſix months a-ſhore at one time, ſince I was a boy, ſo never had opportunity of coming a-long-ſide any but ſuch as your Portſmouth or Plymouth fireſhips, who damage every veſſel they grapple with.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And them, I ſuppoſe, you avoided.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Why, ay—So, d'ye ſee, being lately weather-bound in a trip I made to take obſervation of ſome land that lay a-head of Lady Younglove's, I was forced to put into port at her houſe.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Where you ſaw her beautiful daughter.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: I did, and in the three glaſſes we ſtaid there, ſhe drew my heart with as ſtrong an attraction, as ever the loadſtone did the needle.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Have you communicated your ſentiments to the mother?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No, not yet, but I intend ſhaping my courſe that way directly.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I believe, Captain, I can be of ſervice to you in this affair.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: As how, pray?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am this moment going to pay my addreſſes to the mother.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: What, the old hulk?—Ah, my boy, I'm afraid you are out of your reckoning there—You don't know the trim of her—She'll not be brought to obey either the helm, or the ſheet, and if you'll take my advice, you'll e'en let her drop to pieces where ſhe lies at anchor.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I'll venture, however—The more danger, the more honour, as you ſay; and if you'll aſſiſt me, I don't doubt of ſucceeding.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Well, well, ſince the current of your inclination ſets that way, I ſhan't attempt to ſtem it—thof, let me tell you, ſhe ſaw her two former conſorts go to the bottom, and if you don't take care, you'll ſhare the ſame fate.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I confeſs, I have a terrible proſpect, but nothing ſhall deter me—If you'll ſuſpend your viſit, I'll return as ſoon as our interview is over, and in form you of my ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I ſhall lie by 'till then—But, harkye, Sedley! may I never ſtrike an enemy's flag again, if I would not rather be rak'd fore and aft by a whole French ſquadron, than ſtand one broadſide from ſuch a Turkiſh pirate.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: So, den, de milliner introduce your Lady to de Lord Flamwell?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Oui, I overhear all, and my Lady be juſt gone to her houſe.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Diable! I am almoſt diſtract!—I no ſooner get rid of von rival den anoder ſtart up.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Patience, Monſieur, we go on ver well—So long as we keep Sedley away, we no fear de reſt, but I expect Sir Whifling Trifle, Lady Younglove's broder, tout á l'heure, preſently.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O dat is true, let him come ſo ſoon as he will; I am prepare for him.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Huſh! here he be.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Now, my pretty Mademoiſelle, have I the happineſs of finding your Lady at home?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: No, Monſieur, my Lady be juſt gone out, but here be a Gentleman who has been waiting for you wid de greateſt impatience.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: For me! who is he, pray?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Monſieur le Marquis de Fineſſe, un grand voyageur, who be juſt arrive in England—He hear, par accident, of your viſiting my Lady, ſo—

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Sir, you do me honour.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: So, now I have introduce him; I'll leave you togeder, and go wait for my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, may I without offence know the motive of this Interview?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Curioſity, Monſieur, to ſee ſo great a man, whoſe actions Fame's brazen trompete has blazon'd to every diſtant part of de world.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! this is too much—To be ſure, for theſe thirty years paſt, I've ſpent my whole time in the purſuit of objects diſregarded by the generality of the world; and, I think, I may without vanity ſay, that my labours have been ſucceſsful.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Je le ſais bien, Monſieur, I know it, and from a ſimilarity of diſpoſition beg leave to court your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: I ſhall be proud of the favour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I have myſelf, Monſieur, for deſe many years paſt, been a traveller, and collector of de raritie.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Sir, you pleaſe me very much—may I take the liberty to aſk, where you have been, and what curioſities you have collected?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: De tout mon coeur, Monſieur, wid all my heart—I have travelle over moſht parts of de globe, ſometime I ride, ſometime I valk, ſometime dey carry me againſt my will—Sometime at my own ſharge, and ſometime at de publique expence.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: The public expence?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, Oui, for de good of de nation—Dat is when I be tranſporte.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Ah, that's an honour I am afraid I ſhall never arrive at—But pray let's hear.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: In Italy, Prince Palivicini preſente me wid a piece of de Veſuvian eruption dat choaka Pliny vid its ſmoke.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Wonderful!—But how are you certain of that?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, from a worm-eaten manuſcript preſerve wid it, whereon a P for Pliny, and V for Veſuvio, ſtill viſible.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Proof, proof enough.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, certainement—proof enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Had the whole manuſcript been preſerved it would not have been worth ſix-pence, but the obſcurity always enhances the value.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I ſee you be de true Antiquarian, Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Yes, yes, nobody underſtands theſe things better than I do—I have been in Italy myſelf, and viſited the ruins of Herculaneum.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Well! dere you had ample ſtore.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Ample indeed—They were guarded with the utmoſt ſtrictneſs; nevertheleſs, by liberally bribing the ſeveral perſons appointed to watch them, I found means, at different times, to bring away almoſt a cart-load of legs, arms, and noſes belonging to the mutilated ſtatues.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Eft il bien poſſible?—What a treaſure!

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Yes, and I intend ſhortly publiſhing a dozen volumes folio, proving to demonſtration, the figures they belonged to.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, it will be of vaſt import to de publique.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Very great, I ſhall immortalize my name by it—Travels are ſo much the ton at preſent, that many go abroad on purpoſe to oblige the public at their return, with a relation of their wonderful adventures.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: And you be as well qualified as de beſt of dem.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: I afterwards made ſome important diſcoveries in the North Sea.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: You did!

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Yes, and actually brought away a large piece of ice from thence.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Et bien! Monſieur—Well, and have you it now?

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: No, the heat of the ſun diſſolved it in our voyage home.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Very unfortunate, but travellers are ſubject to diſappointments.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: A la verite, 'tis true, indeed, Monſieur—I have often myſelf experience de ſame—Une autre fois, an oder time I vil give you de whole account of all my voyage, but now let a me beg leave to make you de von little preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Preſent!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui, Monſieur, and ſuch a von as I do flatter myſelf you will not deſpiſe—In my laſt voyage wid Monſ. Bourgainville, touching on de coaſt of Patagonia, I purchaſe from von of deir ſages an ines;timable jewel.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: A jewel!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Not one of doſe ſo called by de Canaille, but an invaluable antique.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Is it poſſible!—I am all impatience—What can it be!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Le Voici, ſee here!— (taking on oyſter-ſhell with great form out of a box)—Behold, an Antideluvian cockle ſhell!

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: I am ſtruck dumb with admiration!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: And well you may—You ſee, Monſieur, by de ſize of it, an undoubted proof of de giantiſm of old.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif. (examining it)
sp.p: Bleſs me!—'Tis as large as a modern oyſter, and I proteſt, ſeems very like one too.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Right, Monſicur, ſo it do—You have de great diſcernment—who knows, indeed noting ſo probable, dan dat de very cockle ſhut up in dis, was Manger, eaten by our grand'mere Eve.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: A happy thought, my friend—Eve's cockle-ſhell! I am raviſh'd at the idea!—But, what return, what recompenſe can I make for a gem of ſuch—

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O, noting at all, but de pleaſure of your acquaintance—I ſhall beg leave to ſee you again, in de evening, at Lady Younglove's.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Dear Sir! you do me too much honour.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: C'eſt Aſſez, Monſieur, enough—But as it is of ſuch conſequence, Sir Whifling, I muſt requeſt you'll immediately go and depoſit it in your cabinet wid your oder curioſities, for fear of accidents.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: That I will, I aſſure you, Sir—I came purpoſely to pay my devoirs to the Goddeſs of this Manſion, but now beg you'll make my excuſes to her—I have now ſomething of more importance to attend to—Yes, yes, I think no one can blame my taſte, in preferring an Antideluvian cockle-ſhell to the fineſt woman in the creation.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! well ſaid, Old Antiquity—Begar, I believe I ſhall put de little ſheat upon him too—Now, to find Sedley again—I have buſineſs enough upon my hand—So much de better——Frenchmen have no occaſion to be idle, when Engliſhmen have ſo many follies and vices to work upon.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Where can this creature be!—Let me ſee— (Looking in the glaſs)—I think this complexion is the moſt agreeable to black—One can't be too nice in ſuiting the complexion to the dreſs.
Where have you been, Frippery?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ordering a freſh quantity of your Ladyſhip's cordial, as you complained that the laſt was not ſtrong enough.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: You are a good girl—Has that impudent fellow, Woodford, been here to-day?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: No, Madam; the anſwer your Ladyſhip gave him yeſterday, will refer him from coming any more.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I am very glad of it—An unmannerly rake-hell, not worth a ſhilling, to have the aſfurance to make love to a child before my face.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: 'Twas monſtraceous rude, indeed, Madam—Had he the ſenſe to have paid his congratulations to your Ladyſhip, he might have been forgiven.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: True, Frippery; I cou'd much ſooner paſs over an affront of that ſort offered to myſelf, than her.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: That I am ſure of— (aſide)—Really, Madam, the exquiſitive charms of your Ladyſhip would be a ſufficient excuſe for ſuch an act of inſenſibility.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O, fie, girl! how can you talk in ſuch a manner?—What charms can a woman of forty be ſuppoſed to have?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Fifty, would be nearer the mark. (aſide.)—Your Ladyſhip certainly miſtakes your age.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: How! miſtake my age—Surely, huſſey, you don't mean—

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; for by your looks, I ſhould take my book oath, that you were not above fiveand-twenty.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh!—Why, I believe I do look very well for my years.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p:
Years!—Lud, Ma'am, how can you talk ſo abruptly?—As I am a woman of veracity, your Ladyſhip only looks like Miſs Flora's eldeſt ſiſter,
and are young enough to have half a dozen huſbands yet.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: You are a merry girl, and always ſtriving to divert your poor diſconſolate miſtreſs—Alas! my ſweet, dear man has been dead above three months, and no one has ſaid a civil thing to me yet.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Sedley, to wait upon your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Shew him up—Bleſs me! what can he want with me?

sp.speaker: Sedley. (bowing)
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip's moſt obedient—How ſhall I apologize for this rudeneſs, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O, dear Sir! there is not the leaſt occaſion—I think you are very kind thus to viſit a poor, diſtreſſed, afflicted widow.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: You are goodneſs itſelf, Madam—I have waited on you now, my Lady, upon a very particular affair, which demands a few moments privacy.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Frippery, you may retire.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady—Hem!—but by virtue of my office, I'll make bold to liſten; ſo, wiſe Sir, you might as well have let me ſtaid.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Now, Madam, that we are alone, can you forgive the folly, the preſumption, the—call it what you pleaſe—which urged me on to this raſh attempt?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I can't comprehend you.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And yet, when you ſhall know how long I have ſighed in ſecret, how long been tortured with deſpair, before I dare pronounce the ſacred name of love—

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Love, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; who could behold ſuch beauty, and not adore?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: So! Miſs has got another lover, I find, but I'll ſoon ſilence him. (aſide) Really, Sir, this is a language I muſt not ſuffer—'Tis highly improper for a child like mine to hear, theſe many years to come.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Child, Madam!—Is it poſſible you can miſtake my meaning?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Why, Sir, was not all this deſigned for my daughter?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: For Miſs Flora, Madam!—No, as your Ladyſhip's daughter, ſhe could not but have ſome charms; but I muſt be blind indeed, to offer up my vows to ſuch a baby—You'll excuſe my freedom, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, readily, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: 'Tis you, my Lady, who are the blooming Goddeſs of my adoration—Oh, how can I expreſs the inconceivable torments of my breaſt, for thoſe many years paſt!—During Sir Solomon's life, fear of offending tied up my tongue to a painful ſilence, and I was obliged to—

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Sir, I pity you, and had I known your ſufferings, wou'd have contrived ſome method of ſoftening them.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am tranſported to hear it—After his death, reſpect ſtill ſealed up my lips, 'till I found—for love, Madam, is Argus-eyed—that Mr. Woodford frequented this houſe, and was, without doubt, a favour'd lover—This made me reſolve to diſcover my hopeleſs paſſion, wait his arrival here, and thro' a happy rival's boſom, force my way to that heart which kings might be proud to call their own!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you are in an error—'Twas not to me, but my daughter, his devoirs were paid.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I cannot ſuppoſe Mr. Woodford ſo inſenſible, as to think of any other object, when you are preſent.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O, dear Sir, he has not half the complaiſance you have!—What a charming man he is!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: My character, and family, Madam, you are no ſtranger to—My eſtate is conſiderable, and, if it is not too great a preſumption, give me leave to caſt both it, and a heart unalterably devoted to you, at your feet.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O, riſe, dear Sir—You overwhelm me with confuſion!—Sure, you cannot poſſibly find any thing ſo attracting in a face, which conſtant grief has made ſuch an impreſſion on.

sp.speaker: Sedley
sp.p: Hem! Now for a little more nonſenſe. (aſide) Come, my beauteous widow, caſt aſide theſe weeds of ſorrow, and be arrayed in robes more ſplendid, and more becoming ſuch a divinity.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Impoſſible—I fear, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Impoſſble!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Almoſt, Sir—What will the world ſay of ſo haſty, ſo precipitate an act?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Umph! I find her coming. (aſide) Love, Madam, will plead for all—'Tis a crime againſt his power to reſiſt—Beſides, enough you have ſacrificed to ſorrow—Three months at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, more—Sixteen weeks tomorrow—But, what are ſixteen weeks, ſixteen months, or ſixteen years, to mourn the loſs of ſo good a man.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Come, Madam, no more of theſe melancholy reflections—The only remedy in the world for a lady's immoderate grief on the loſs of a favourite, be it monkey, lap-dog, or huſband, is to get another.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I believe you are perfectly right—I remember, ſome years ago, I was utterly inconſolable on the death of a beautiful parrot, 'till the loſs was ſupplied by an enchanting owl, which was preſented me.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Then let me, Madam, by the warmth of my paſſion, dry up your tears for Sir Solomon Younglove.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Surely, Sir, you are uncommonly perſuading—Well! to try your conſtancy, if you perſevere in your intention, till my year of widowhood be expired, I don't know but I may be tempted to reward it.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: A year, Madam!—An age!—For heaven's ſake, my dear Lady, have ſome compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, I am very compaſſionate.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me die at your feet?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: No, not for the world—Rather than you ſhould do that, I will ſhorten it—to—to half the time.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: She ſoon drops. (aſide) Still, madam, I find you are cruelly reſolved not to make me happy, therefore hopeleſs, and deſpairing, let me bid you eternally, eternally, adieu!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Stay, ſir, ſtay—Muſt not I pay my laſt huſband the ſame compliment I did my firſt?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: What was that madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Wait five ſhort, ſhort months.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Look you, my Lady, I would do as I would be done by—If you ſurvive me, you have my conſent to marry again the next day.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I confeſs, ſir, you are the moſt reaſonable man I ever met with.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: But, I ſee, madam, you are inexorable, ſo muſt retire, and in ſecret, lament my adverſe fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Dear ſir, ſtay—What can I ſay? I vow you are quite irreſiſtible—Well, then,—though overwhelm'd with bluſhes—To-morrow, I conſent to be yours.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Retard not my joy ſo long, but let this night crown my happineſs—I ſee a kind conſenting ſmile ſparkle in your eye, and thus, I thank you (Kiſſes her) Oh, zounds! that was too much!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Who can withſtand ſuch rhetoric!—You have conquered, ſir, and I ſurrender at diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And now, my dear Lady, as our intereſts are to be one—If you give me leave, I can aſſiſt you in diſpoſing of Miſs Flora.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: You cou'd not oblige me more, ſir, for, poor child! ſhe ſeems in great haſte to be married.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Not ſo much as her mother, I'll be ſworn. (aſide) I think, my Lady, I could recommend one you can have no objection to—Captain Helm, your neighbour.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Captain Helm—Do you think that poſſible?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Nothing eaſier, if your Ladyſhip does not chuſe to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I prevent it; heavens forbid!—Poor dear child, it wou'd be a happy day for her.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Happy, indeed, madam.—He has been raving about Miſs, ever ſince his accidentally ſeeing her in the country, and longing for an opportunity of declaring himſelf—Nay, more—he knows of my viſit to you, and hopes this evening will unite both parties.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I'm ſure I would do any thing in reaſon to ſecure her felicity.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Captain Helm, madam, is prodigiouſly in love, vet has many odd whims, and like the element he belongs to, is very ſubject to change.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, if he was once bound, we'd give him leave to change.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: True, madam, therefore we had better make ſhort work of it, and take him while he is in the humour.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p:
Well! do juſt as you pleaſe, dear
Mr. Seley—I am now your property, ſo diſpoſe of me and mine, as you like.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I'll ſtep directly to my lawyer's to prepare the deeds, then return with Captain Helm—Meantime, my lovely charmer! diveſt yourſelf of thoſe beauty-veiling weeds, relumine the circle you were wont to ſhine in, and prepare to bleſs the happieſt mortal in the world!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: What a bewitching man!—But, there is not a moment to loſe, I muſt ſet about making the neceſſary preparations immediately—Well, who could have thought when I got up this morning, that I ſhould be a bride before night.—O, lud! a third huſband is a happineſs I never expected.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: So! Upon my word, a tender ſcene, and quite curry-curriſtical—When Miſs and her old ſeamonſter join them, they'll make a nice trio—But, it is unpoſſible all this can be real on his ſide; and if my old Lady was not ſo toſticated with her good fortune, ſhe might eaſily find it out—Oh, here comes Miſs, now we ſhall hear her ſentances of the matter.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Frippery, what's the matter with my mama? I met her this moment in unuſual ſpirits, and ſhe ordered me to follow her into her dreſſing-room.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Spirits!—A third huſband is enough to put any woman turned of ſifty into ſpirits—Heaven help me! though I am half that age, I have not got one yet.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: What do you mean, Frippery?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I mean, that your mama's going to be married, to-night.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: To-night!

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yes, to-night.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: More ſhame for her.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ay, ſo ſay I.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I'm ſure it wou'd be fitter for her to get me a huſband firſt.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh! you are to be married at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Am I?—I'm afraid that's too good news to be true.—But tell me ſincerely, are not you joking now?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Not I, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well, that is charming!—Only feel what a palpitation it has cauſed here,—for all the world like the fluttering of my little Robin Red-breaſt.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ay, my dear, I have often had ſuch fluſtrations.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: And does Mr. Woodford know it?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Mr. Woodford, Lord, Miſs, he is not to be the man.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: No!—Who then?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why, his uncle, Captain Helm, who you remember viſited us ſome time ago in the country.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: What, that ugly old fright, who I compar'd to King Priam in the puppet-ſhew?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: The very idential man, Miſs.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Was there ever anything ſo ridiculous!—A huſband, Ha! ha! ha!—O yes, to be ſure he's a very proper huſband for a girl of my age and ſpirit.—It is a wonder, Frippery, ſhe did not think of a dancing bear for me—I'm ſure, he's much the more agreeable and poliſh'd animal of the two.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Indeed, Miſs, I muſt ſay, that he's the moſt oddeſt, damphibious looking creature I ever ſaw—But your mama intends to make you have him, or not a penny of fortune.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
A fig for fortune, ſay I.—Before ſhe ſhould ſacrafice me to ſuch a compound of age and infirmity, I'd bid adieu to all ideas of future grandeur,
and boldly fly, with the man of my heart, to thoſe regions of love and happineſs, where true content is only to be found.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lady deſires you, Mrs. Frippery, to go directly for her diamond ear-rings, that are mending at the jeweller's, and not to ſtay a moment, for ſhe wants you in all haſte to help her to dreſs.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: So! ſhe's in a hurry, I find.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Hurry! ecod, I believe ſhe's poſſeſt—ſhe has order'd us all to get on our ſtate liveries, that were made in her firſt huſband's time, and the houſekeeper is to provide ſuch a ſupper, that, lud have mercy upon me!—Hark! her bell rings.— [Exit; returns.] Oh, I had forgot—Miſs Flora, you are to go to your mama directly.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Tell her, I won't, John.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: No, John, tell her ſhe's coming.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Well, do juſt as you pleaſe for that.—Coming, my Lady, coming—Zounds! I wiſh the bell was tied about your neck.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: My dear, you muſt go—endeavour to humour your mama now.—Only ſeem to be agreeable to her marriage, and perhaps ſhe may not inſiſt on yours.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Nay, I did not care if ſhe married a new huſband every month, ſo ſhe'd only let me have Mr. Woodford; and I'm ſure that's not unreaſonable.—But will you, my dear Frippery, in the mean time, endeavour to find him out, and let him know my diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: That I will, I'll enſure you.—Do you think I cou'd refuſe any thing in my power, to help ſuch a couple of true lovyers?—No, no, Frippery always does as ſhe'd be done by—and, I'm ſure all I wait for myſelf is,—the man to aſk me the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well!—Some girls now, in my ſituation, wou'd, in deſpair of relief, hang or drown themſelves, and ſo put an end to their adventures at once. To be ſure, my ſituation is very critical—Solely dependant on a mother—Denied the man I love, and obliged to receive the odious addreſſes of one I hate, are difficulties not eaſily ſurmounted—Yet, a good heart, and a fertile head, may do much—And if I do ſurmount them, I think I ſhall deſerve a ſtatue raiſing to my conſtancy and fidelity.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Well, my good mother, what ſucceſs?—I have been upon the rack ever ſince you went—Come, tell me—Any hopes?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Hopes!—When did you know me undertake any thing that fail'd?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: But, have you mention'd me?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have done more for you than ever your own mother did—Look you, I expect no leſs than a thouſand pounds for my ſhare—Ay, all ſigned and ſealed before conſummation.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: You ſhall have it without the leaſt ſcruple.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Scruple, indeed!—A hundred a year for life.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: An elegant houſe, ready furniſhed.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: All very reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Ay, I was always remarked for my reaſon and moderation.—Well! after this affair is over, I ſhall have nothing to do, but to live with credit and character, the reſt of my days.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Then you think we ſhall ſucceed?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Quite certain of it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: You tranſport me!

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Such a lovely, tender, ſweet chicken!—Ah, rogue, if you ſhould not behave well to her, you'll break my heart.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Oh, never fear that—You know I am a man of the ſtricteſt honour.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Yes, I have had many proofs of your honour. (aſide.) Ay, 'tis that conſideration alone which urges me on—I would not have helped her to every body, for heaven knows, it is not the little traſh I am to get by it, that—

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: No, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: I ſay, 'tis not the trifle I am to get by it, but the ſurety of providing her with a good huſband.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: But all this while you keep me in ſuſpence—What ſaid ſhe?—When may I hope to ſee her?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Said! no bird ever fell into a fowler's ſnare ſo readily—She believes every ſyllable about your title and fortune, is as impatient as you are for an interview, and promis'd to be here directly.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Egad, you have made quick work of it—Be here directly—Zounds! I am afraid I ſhall want aſſurance to go through with it.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: After what you have gone through already, I think there can be no great danger now.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: You muſt introduce me properly, elſe, as I have never ſeen her, I may make ſome miſtake.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: I muſt own your head is not the beſt in the world, but here you can't readily go wrong—Be fure you keep up to your part—Talk of the years you have been dying for her in ſecret—Flatter her charms to the utmoſt—Speak highly of your family and connections—If you ſhould make ſome trifling blunders, I'll place them to the exceſs of your paſſion—The moſt pleaſing excuſe which can be given to a woman fond of adoration.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: As for that matter, you know I am ſeldom at a loſs for words.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Yes, I know the height of your oratory, but let me tell you, ſhe muſt be attack'd in a very different manner from the nymphs you have been uſed to.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll take care now to be on the other ſide, and be as high-flown as poſſible—I have been ſtudying hard words for that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: As I live, that's her rap—She's impatient indeed!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Zounds! I am quite unprepared—What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Receive her as if by accident—She'll pretend ſhe's come to me, but I'll not appear till the firſt ceremonies are over.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Hold—Don't leave us together.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Not another word, but make good uſe of your time.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I wiſh with all my ſoul, it was over—Hem! hem!

sp.speaker: Flam. (In confuſion)
sp.p: Ma'am—your—your—moſt unlimitedly—obedient—I, I am—that is to ſay—extravagantly happy—in—in—in—

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: I was told, ſir, that Mrs. Faſhion was here.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Ay, that's right. (aſide) Hem! hem!—She only gave place, illuſtrious Lady, to let the reſplendency of your charms ſhine in their meridian luſtre!—Hem! hem!

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Sir!—Is it to me you addreſs this diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Who elſe, thou ſovereign object of my wiſhes!—I have languiſh'd whole years for the happineſs of this interview, and now, I—

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Hold, ſir,—I am not to be treated in this ludicrous manner—Do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p:
Do the inhabitants of this nether world know the radiant ſun that daily illumines them?—
You, my angelic Miſs Bloomer, are my ſun, my moon, my ſtars, my whole planetary ſyſtem!—Pretty well that, I think.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Miſs Bloomer!—Ha! there muſt be ſome trick in this—Some deſign on my fair friend—I'll fathom it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: She heſitates—I believe I have done it—Bravo, my boy, I never knew your eloquence fail.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, who are you?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Ah, madam! I am the unhappy Lord Flamwell, heir to one of the moſt noble families in England, with an independant fortune in my own poſſeſſion, which, with the moſt glowing heart that ever was offered up to Cytherea's goddeſs, I now preſent to you, my Cyprian Venus.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: And all this is deſigned for me?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Alas! where's the merit in paying worſhip to the queen of beauty?—No, my adorable Miſs Bloomer, I long have loved, but till this happy moment, never had courage to tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: And I am to believe all this real?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Every ſyllable of it true, by thoſe bright eyes!

div.p: My dear Miſs Bloomer! this is ſo kind of you to call on—Ah! what do I ſee!—Miſs Belgrove!—My Lord, what are you about?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Curſe me if I know!— (Riſes, looks confuſedly, firſt at Miſs Belgrove, then at Mrs. Faſhion)—Oh, my evil ſtars! what have I done now?

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Upon my word, Mrs. Faſhion, I am very glad you are come—You, perhaps, can explain this gentleman's meaning, which, I confeſs, is above my comprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p:
My dear, ſweet Miſs Belgrove—This
gentleman—is a—a Lord—that—that—a—his friends have confined in my houſe for lunacy.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Mrs. Faſhion, I did not know till now, that you kept a private madhouſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Ah, poor nobleman! he's greatly to be pitied—All this is a love affair, Miſs—Gone quite diſtracted for love.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: For love!—And are you ſo famous for curing mad people?—Now, I think I could recommend a magiſtrate for his doctor, who could much ſooner reſtore him to his ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Oh, your Ladyſhip miſtakes him quite—As innocent as a new-born babe—But, pray let me attend you into another room.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: I ſhan't ſtop—I only wanted to conſult you about the choice of ſome Bruſſells lace.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: I'll wait on your Ladyſhip, at your own houſe directly.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Whenever you are at leiſure.—Mean time, let me adviſe that gentleman, not to be ſo violent in his raptures, before he is certain of the perſon he addreſſes them to.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Ah, you are a witty Lady—Nay, by my ſaith, I'll wait on you to the door—This is ſo great an honour to call (Turns and looks back at Flamwell) Ah! conjuror.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Tol, lol, lol. (ſinging) I believe it is all over—Ay, ay, my old luck purſues me ſtill, and if ever I do cut a diſtinguiſning figure in the world, I'm afraid it will be when I make my exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant, good Mr. Blunder—You have made a notable piece of work here.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Hang, or drown yourſelf—'tis all over now.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Was there ever ſo unlucky a dog!

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Never—that I'll anſwer for—Nothing proſpers you undertake—What the deuce could poſſeſs you to make ſo egregious a miſtake?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Zounds! you—You knew I had never ſeen Miſs Bloomer, and your declaring it was her, left me not the leaſt room to doubt.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Nothing could be more unfortunate!—The two ladies are intimate, and if a diſcovery ſhould enſue, I am entirely ruined.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Can you think of nothing to prevent it?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: I expect the real Miſs Bloomer every minute—When ſhe's gone, I'll wait upon Miſs Belgrove, and endeavour to perſuade her, that you really are a lunatic—And faith, if this affair fails, I ſhall be little better myſelf. (Knocking) Hark! I believe this is ſhe, in reality—Away, and be in readineſs, if I ſhould want you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Hearky'!—Take care how you introduce me to the next Miſs Bloomer.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Now, Faſhion, I am as good as my word, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs you! that you always are.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: But come, I have not a moment to loſe.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Ah, that ſweet countenance!—I don't wonder ſo many gentlemen deſpair of obtaining ſo great a prize.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: I am ſure I can't blame the extravagance of Lord Flamwell's paſſion—And, by my faith, he ſwears he can't live without you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Lord Flamwell!—Who is he, pray?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: The young nobleman, I told your Ladyſhip about this morning—Well, a ſweeter, better humour'd, or more generous man, was never ſeen—Had you beheld with what tranſports he received the news of your coming hither.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Why, ſurely, you did not tell him any ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Really, Miſs, he look'd ſo piteouſly, I cou'd not help it—Oh, Mrs. Faſhion, ſays he, if my beauteous angel will but conſent to be mine, how happy ſhall I be!—My whole fortune ſhall be at her command—What pleaſure ſhall I take in introducing her to my Siſters, Lady Lucy, Lady Sophia, and Lady Harriet.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Bleſs me! the Gentleman ſeems to have a number of relations—But I have not time to loſe about ſuch trifles.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Do you call breaking a nobleman's heart, a trifle?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Yes—to me the greateſt trifle in the world.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Ah, you'll pay for all, one day or other—But, do now, give me leave to introduce him to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Who, me?—Not I, I poſitively aſſure you—'Tis your own houſe, you know, and if you chuſe to do it—I can't help you.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Well, I'll venture your diſpleaſure—I'm ſure you would not be the death of any perſon, nor diſcompoſe that ſweet face of yours with a frown, for the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: What a fool am I, to be flatter'd by ſuch a fulſome old woman—I am certainly an odd compoſition—to be pleaſed with what at the ſame time I ſo much deſpiſe—Now, for my Lord—If his heart does not ſpeedily go pit-a-pit, and I don't make him as great a rool as I have dome the reſt of my admirers, why I'll conteſs, I've loſt the art of tormenting.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Miſs Bloomer, Lord Flamwell, who has long wiſh'd to pay his reſpects to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Hold, my Lord, we muſt be upon a more intimate footing, before I allow liberties of that ſort.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I ſtand juſtly reproved, Madam, for my preſumption, and own I merit the fate of—of—Icarus, who drove the Chariot of Apollo—Yet, if you'll but—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Your Lordſhip muſt pardon this emotion, which the profundity of your learning has involuntarily extorted from me—Ha! ha! ha! If I don't miſtake, Icarus was a near relation of yours.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Of mine, Madam,—Yes—No, no, he has been dead, for ought I can tell, theſe—theſe hundred years paſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I know it, my Lord, but you certainly are of the ſame family, and endeavour to imitate him, in ſoaring ſo high.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: If I have committed any error, your charms, Madam, are a ſufficient excuſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: True, my Lord, my charms have led many people into very great errors, and if you don't take care, you'll ſtand in the ſame predicament.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I wiſh it, Madam.—If I am ſo conſpicuouſly happy, as to poſſeſs you, I ſhall be the envy of the gaping world—Adorable creature! behold, thus proſtrate at your feet, the unhappy Lord Flamwell, who vows never more to riſe, till you have put a period to his ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: And that, I vow, my Lord, will never be.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Ah, the ſweet youth! it brings tears into my eyes, to ſee what a condition love has reduced him to.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p:
Pray, my Lord, let's have that ſpeech
over again—Stay, you ſhall ſee how gracefully it comes from me in heroics.
sp.l: Thus at your feet, Pompoſo Flamwell lies,
There vows to ſtay, until you bid him—riſe.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I find ſhe's an overmatch for me, every way.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Come, Miſs Bloomer, let me put in a word for his Lordſhip—As I can anſwer for the ſincerity and honourableneſs of his intentions, I hope you'll not ſtand on unneceſſary punctilio—You ſee he cannot live without you—Reward his paſſion with your hand, and let me this evening, ſalute you Lady Flamwell.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Thou, more than Goddeſs! if you judge my fortune, title, or family, not beneath your acceptance, bleſs me with your love, and crown my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Ay, I ſee a kind conſenting look in theſe pretty tell-tale ſparklers—Juſt ſo, I look'd myſelf, on ſuch an occaſion—By my faith, we'll have a wedding directly—Let your Lordſhip's Chaplain be call'd in, and the ceremony immediately performed.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Hold, hold, pray let me get in a word with you—Look you, my Lord, I have not been uſed to ſuch treatment, nor do I underſtand your meaning—As to you, Mrs. Faſhion, I am ſurprized you don't know me better—But, be aſſur'd, as this is the firſt time I've been in your houſe, ſo it ſhall be the laſt.

sp.speaker: Flam. (Kneeling.)
sp.p: Stay, charming, cruel tyrant, and take my life before you go.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: What uſe ſhall I make of it, my Lord?—You had better make a preſent of it to ſome other perſon, who prefers a title before underſtanding, and wealth beyond happineſs.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: My dear Miſs Bloomer, how can you be angry with me?—If my Lord loves you to diſtraction, am I to blame, in endeavouring to promote your future felicity?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Then will you not give me leave to hope?—And muſt thoſe charms, which like the ſun diſpenſe their refreſhing beams around the celeſtial hemiſphere, be only withheld from me?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: My Lord, tho' I believe nobility and common ſenſe very compatible, yet, as you are not happily poſſeſſed of both, forgive me if I decline your very generous offer—And, be certain, if ever I do reſign my freedom, it ſhall be to a man who knows how to ſet a proper value on it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: And, curſe catch me! if ever I am maſter of 〈◊〉 , if I don't make you heartily repent this treatment.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Go, you deſerve it all, for being ſo great an ideot.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Zounds! woman, what would you have me do?—I ſpoke better than ever I did in my life before, but the Devil is not a match for ſuch a tongue.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: No, not ſuch an ignorant Devil as you—But, ſhe ſhan't eſcape ſo—Ill after her, and endeavour to repair your miſtakes, then make my laſt bold effort—So, prepare yourſelf—the concluſion of this buſineſs will certainly be a wife, or—a halter!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: A wife, by all means—Of Two Evils, I always chuſe the leaſt.

div.stage: Enter Lady YOUNGLOVE, dreſt, and FLORA,

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: How can you, Child, make all this noiſe about One Huſband, when you ſee, I have been oblig'd to have Two already, and am now under the cruel neceſſity of preparing for a Third.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Yes, and that ſame cruel neceſſity would oblige you to marry a ſcore, if you could.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Sedley, and Capt. Helm, to wait upon your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Admit them.

div.stage: Enter SEDLEY, Capt. HELM, and SWAB.
div.p: Gentlemen, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: So, Widow! I underſtand you are hound for another voyage—Lookee, if the wind ſits fair, belike I ſhall bear you company.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you, Captain, for your good wiſhes, and hope my daughter may entertain a proper ſenſe of them.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O, yes, he may be aſſur'd, that I entertain a very proper ſenſe of them.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Thank you, thank you, Widow—Suppoſe I haul a chair, and ſound the coaſt, to ſee how the land lies.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Do, Captain—meantime, my fair widow and I have ſome private affairs to ſettle, that will require our abſence for a few minutes—Madam, will you indulge me ſo far—

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I can't deny you any thing you aſk—
sp.stage: [Sedley hands her out with great ceremony.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: So, ſo!—they have left me to the mercy of this frightful Man of War—Now, for a love-ſcene of the tendereſt kind.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Swab! go below—And, d'ye ſee, look out for a ſnug birth, call for a can of flip, and keep a tight reckoning, till I pipe you up again.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I will, your honour, and drink ſucceſs to the chace.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Now we are alone, I don't know what to ſay to her—By the meſs, I begin to find I've got out of my element.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well, I really think he is ten times uglier than when I ſaw him laſt.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hem?—If I was but once afloat, ſhou'd do well enough.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
