What a pretty lover he makes—Poor
wretch!—I think I muſt plague him a little—Yes, yes, I muſt have ſome ſport with him.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: That it ſhou'd ever come to this!—I who have attacked ſo many firſt-rate men of war, now to be afraid of a little cock-boat.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Pray, Captain, what makes you look ſo very grum?—If you are not well. I'll go and fetch ſome of my Mama's ſtomachic cordial for you.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hold, Miſs, I am pretty well, thank you—Hem!— (After ſome preparation) Pray, Miſs, were you ever at ſea?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: A good beginning—O, yes, Captain, very often—Why, I once went with my mama as far as Greenwich.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Well, Miſs, what think you now, of a voyage to the Land of Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Voyage!—Why, I always thought that people went by land to be married—Now, I ſhou'd like to be married very well,—but not to you.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: All above board, I find—Mayhap, Miſs, you may think my timbers are not ſound, and that I want to be hove down—But, let me tell you, I am heartier than many, whoſe gingerbread rigging fly full in the wind's eye.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Gingerbread rigging!—I'm ſure, I'd rather have a gingerbread huſband, than you.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, why ſo?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Becauſe, when I was tired of playing with it, I could eat it.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Nay, if you be like the cannibals, Miſs, I had beſt ſheer off—tho', I believe you'd find me very hard of digeſtion.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Very likely, but I ſhan't try.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: However, Miſs, all this is little to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ay, indeed, and ſo it is ſure enough—So, as you have nothing more to ſay, I think I had beſt leave you to yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Avaſt, avaſt!—If you are for running a-head ſo, I muſt bring you to your bearings.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ah, but you can't tho', for I never will bear you.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Lookee, d'ye ſee, Miſs, I came hither to have ſome ſerious diſcourſe with you, becauſe as how I intended to have meſs'd with you for life, but if ſo be you can't ſteer a ſteady courſe without all this tacking, why, it will be a thing impoſſible to grapple with you for half a glaſs together.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well, then, I will ſpeak my mind, tho' Mama ſhou'd lock me up for it—I deteſt the ſight of you—if you were as handſome as you are ugly, and as young as you are old, yet ſtill I ſhou'd hate you—My heart is ſet upon Mr. Woodford, and have him I will, tho' I creep through an iron grate, or jump out of a garret window to him.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: So! ſhe has ſlipt her anchor, and run out to ſea; while I am all aground here, and muſt wait for a ſpring tide to ſet me afloat again.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Sedley, your arguments are ſo perſuaſive, there's no reſiſting them—I conſent then, that both marriages be celebrated this evening.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And, to free you from any jealouſy of Miſs Bloomer, I requeſt, Madam, that ſhe may be invited as a witneſs, on this joyful occaſion.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I vow, that's cruel in you, beſides, poor Lady! it will look like inſult in me—But, bleſs me, Captain, where's the child gone to?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Right a head, yonder, ſailing in the wind's eye.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Well, Captain, what ſucceſs?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Succeſs!—Why, d'ye ſee, I believe I have ſteer'd by a wrong chart, and mayhap, if I don't tack about, I may chance to be wreck'd upon the ſhallows.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p:
Oh, dear Captain, von muſt not mind
her—She's young and ignorant of her good—I was juſt ſo 〈◊〉 her age, but ſhe'll know better before long.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, Widow, I do think ſhe 〈◊〉 a little teaching, and will lay a wager, ſhe does not know a cat from a capſtan—But, no matter for that,—all in good time—patience is a good ſtream anchor—If I thought I ſtood fair for the harbour of her good-will, why, 'tis not a little ſqually weather, or variation of the wind, ſhould hinder 〈◊〉 from venturing.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I'll enſure your ſuccessing—My Lady and I have entirely ſettled matters—At our return in the evening, every thing is to be finally concluded—You'll have your writings ready.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I can produce the log-book of my eſtate at a minute's warning.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And, Captain, I think the greateſt puniſhment you can inflict on your nephew for his diſobedience, will be to oblige him to be a ſpectator of the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Right, my Boy, ſo it will.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A letter for Mr. Sedley.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: For me!—With your leave, my Lady.—

body.p: —If there remains the leaſt ſpark of tenderneſs in your boſom for Miſs Bloomer, fly to extricate her from an affair that threatens the deſtruction of her peace and happineſs—There is no time to be loſs—Come to my Houſe directly, and I'll inform you of particulars.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Miſs Bloomer!—Her very name has raiſed a tumult in my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Sedley, you ſeem diſcompoſed—

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: No, Madam, perfectly eaſy.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Sure no unlucky accident has happened to diſturb our happineſs?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: No, Madam, none.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I'm afraid there has,—You had better ſtay here till every thing is over.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Fulſome old Witch! (aſide) Importance, Madam, ſome urgent buſineſs demands me for a little time—I ſhall not ſtav long.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Mr. Sedley—And may I depend upon you?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Stay, Mr. Sealey—Perhaps, this is ſome affair with a lady, and—

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Don't be uneaſy, Madam,—Was there ever an 〈◊〉 ſo provoking (aſide.) Captain, you'll excuſe me, I'll ſend up your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: 〈…〉 ſtay, another word—Had not I better 〈…〉 then—

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, ſtay till I come back, and then—your may go to Jamaica, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, the ſweet creature!—I wiſh this affair was over—If I ſhould be diſappointed now—Well, I ſhan't have a moment's comfort, till I have abſolutely ſecured him mine.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: And, noint my block, if ever you'll let him have a moment's comfort afterwards.

div.p: Steady, boys, ſteady!

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hey!—Avaſt!—What's here?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: All's ſafe—all's ſafe, your honour— (hiccups)ſteady, ſteady's the word—No • ear of b •• ging, 〈◊〉 Swab keeps a dead reckoning.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: You lubberly dog! how came you in this trim?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: No matter—All's ſafe—I've been toſſing the Can to Mrs. Erippery's health—And now, if your worſhip's gl •• y vill turn out, we will ſcud homewards with a 〈◊〉 gale.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: You deſerve to be laſh'd to the gangway, you drunken water-ſpout, and if I come along ſide of you, I'll be ſoon foul of your forelights.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Bleſs you precious limbs, no, no, noble Captain, ſafe's the word, ſafe's the word—I'm the man will ſtand by you, while I have a ſtick ſtanding, or can carry a rag of canvaſs—So, follow in my wake, as ſoon as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Sheer off—do—The dog knows I regard him for old acquantance ſake,—To be ſure, a better ſailor never ſtep'd upon forecaſtle—He has work'd many a hard gale, and never flinched—ah! 'tis ſuch brave fellows as he, that man our fleets, and ſhew our topſails to the enemy—Ay, ay, Old England may well ſay, that a Britiſh ſeaman, is one of the nobieſt characters, the word can boaſt of.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I Own to you, Miſs Belgrove, that, ſo far from being indifferent about Miſs Bloomer, my heart never was more devoted to her, than at preſent—In vain, my reaſon ſhews the folly of my conduct, love has got poſſeſſion of my ſoul with ſuch abſolute dominion, that every other paſſion bows to its reſiſtleſs ſway.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Certainly, you Lovers, are the moſt inconſiſtent ſet of beings in the world—Abſolute contradictions—You love and hate, ſwear and forſwear, whine and rage;—Reſolve one moment, and break it the next—Tear the falſe image from your hearts this hour, and worſhip it with the groſſeſt adulation the following one.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I confeſs it, Madam, yet in me you'll not behold ſuch a Proteus—I can love, without being blind.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Impoſſible, for all lovers are blind, at leaſt to the faults of their miſtreſſes—But, no more of this—Take my word for it, Miſs Bloomer is deſerving of your beſt wiſhes, and, tho' I cannot entirely defend the ſprightly, tho' ſometimes, imprudent ſallies of my fair friend; yet, I think them ſo venially agreeable, that they almoſt carry their excuſe in the commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And, yet, in the preſent caſe, 'tis certain ſhe encourages the addreſſes of ſome deſigning raſcal, who, probably wants to make a prey of her perſon and fortune.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: I own it looks like it—When I ſaw her this morning, ſhe hinted a new conqueſt of a Lord, and by the circumſtances, I ſuſpect Mrs. Faſhion of being the contriver of the whole deſign.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Have you ſeen Miſs Bloomer ſince you left Mrs. Faſhion's?

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: No, I called at her houſe directly after, but ſhe was not at home, upon which, apprehending ſome bad conſequences, I thought the beſt thing I could do, would be to acquaint you, and requeſt your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: You oblige me infinitely, Madam—I'll unravel this villainy, or—

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Stay, do nothing unadviſedly—Let me go again to Miſs Bloomer's, and endeavour to learn whether ſhe has ſeen this impoſtor.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: You are right, Madam—But, pray, don't drop a hint of your ſuſpicions—Conviction will come ſtronger, when attended with danger, and open detection—Meanwhile, I'll juſt ſtep home, and be back time enought for your return.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman!—Oh, Lud! what fools this Love makes of the wiſeſt of us—I ſwear, if the whimſical, inconſiſtent urchin, dare have the aſſurance to attack me, I'd muſter up all my courage, and—and—run away from him, as faſt as I could.

div.stage: Enter Miſs BLOOMER, and Mrs. FASHION.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Faſh.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Lady! what an unfortunate woman am I?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what new matter for wonder?—Have you made another miſtake?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Surely, I was born to be unhappy!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I can't help ſaying, you deſerve it—The next time I call at your houſe, you ſhall ſuffer me to be affronted in the manner I was laſt.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: You have ample revenge, I can aſſure you—Oh, I ſhall never forgive myſelf, no, not if I was to live a thouſand years, for being acceſſary to the death of ſo ſweet, ſo lovely, ſo good-natured a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Death! whoſe death?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: And yet, alas! I am innocent—'Tis thoſe bright eyes alone, that have done all this miſchief.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Oh, if that be all, I'll readily undertake to cure all the evil done by them.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: No, no, he's too far gone to cure—He's a dying man.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Dying!—Who in the name of wonder is dying?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Lord Flamwell—No ſooner had you left the houſe, than, ſeiz'd with a fit of deſpair, he ſhut himſelf up in his chamber, and—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Rayed like a madman, then, when he was tired—let himſelf out again.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: How can you be ſo barbarous!—But mark the conſequences—He had ſearce been a quarter of an hour there, when we were alarmed with the groans of a dying perſon, and forcing the door open, found him weltring in his blood.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Oh, heavens! is it true?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: A ſurgeon was immediately ſent for, but on examination, he declared the wound mortal, and that nothing could ſave his life.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I am petrified with horror!

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh! (crying) that ever I ſhould live to ſee this day!—The ſweet youth!—I loved him, as if he had been my own ſon!—What will his family ſay to me?—Oh! oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: But, are there no hopes of his recovery?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: No, not the leaſt—He can't live two hours!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Poor gentleman!—I ſincerely pity him.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Ah! what ſignifies pity—If you would make him ſome amends for your cruelty, and condeſcend to viſit him directly—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I viſit him!

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Yes—conſider can you be ſo hard-hearted as refuſe him the only conſolation he can receive in his laſt moments?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: You do not ſurely adviſe me to it.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: From my ſoul I do—Dear Mrs. Faſhion, ſaid he, in faltering accents—Go to the unrelenting fair one, tell her, I die the victim of her obduracy—True, I was not worthy of aſpiring to ſuch excellence—But, if ſhe will deign once more to look upon me, I'll implore her forgiveneſs, and, as a ſmall atonement for my folly and preſumption, requeſt her acceptance of my fortune—That, though ſhe could not love me living, ſhe may compaſſionate my memory.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: His generoſity affects me—I heartily with he may recover, but beg leave to decline his offer.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Really, Miſs, I did not think you could have been ſo ungrateſul—What harm can there be in viſiting a dying man?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I am abore ſuſpecting any harm, but ſcorn to take advantage of his weakneſs for me.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: 'Tis no advantage—What do his friends value the few thouſands he can beſtow?—Come, I muſt perſuade you to accept them.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Indeed, Mrs. Faſhion, though I am far from being void of humanity, yet upon this occaſion you muſt excuſe me; you may aſſure him, that, if wiſnes—

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: No, no,—In all probability, he will not be alive in an hour's time—The very ſight of you wou'd ſatisfy him, and then he would die contented.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?—

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Nay, don't heſitate at performing a charitable action.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Well, well—You have perſuaded me.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Ah, you are a ſweet, good Lady, and I hope will be rewarded for your tenderneſs—Then, you promiſe to come immediately?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Bleſſings on that complying countenance!—Could I but live to ſee you married to my wiſh, I ſhould then be a happy woman!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: So! ſo!—Theſe eyes of mine will be brought in guilty of murder!—Well! I am certainly an unaccountable mortal—Though my heart feels the moſt delicate touches of ſenſibility, yet, this love of admiration hurries me, unthinkingly, into a thouſand errors—Poſitively, I will reform—Ay, but how?—Why, marry—Oh, lud, the cure would be worſe than the diſeaſe—And yet, was Sedley my doctor, I think he cou'd qualify the bitter portion—In 〈◊〉 , I'm abſolutely determined—on—what? To be as good as I can.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Talk not of danger, my ſweet girl! who could be ſeparated from you ſo long, and not purchaſe ſuch precious moments at any riſque?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O dear! what a bounce my heart gave when I ſaw you—I'm frightened out of my wits at your raſhneſs—If my Mamma catches us, we are undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: You need not fear, Miſs, your Mamma's in too great a concatenation herſelf, tomind you; and ſhe has ſent all the ſervants out, about one fribalous thing, or other—However, to make ſure, I'll ſtand centry myſelf for you, ſo make good uſe of your time, you young rogues.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p:
My impatience would not let me wait the ſucceſs of a ſcheme I had concerted with Sedley, this
morning; I was reſolved to ſee you, ſo made uſe of my key of the gate at the end of the lane, to let myſelf into the garden, from whence I ſlipt up the back ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: You are too ventureſome, yet, I'm glad you are come to my relief—My Mamma inſiſts poſitively upon my marrying your Uncle to-night.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I know it, my angel, but we will diſappoint her, if you'll conſent to let me convey you to a place where we may be united beyond the power of ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I would run any hazard to avoid ſo hateful a union—And, yet, Woodford, ſhould you behave unkindly to me, when I'm under your protection, it would break my heart.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: He muſt be a villain indeed, who could wrong ſuch innocence—No, rely upon my truth and honour—Let me but lead you from hence, now we have this favourable opportunity, and before we are miſſed, I hope we ſhall be far enough out of the reach of a purſuit.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: With all my heart—For, to confeſs the truth, I ſhould like to be run away with into Scotland above all things—O lud! it will be ſo pleaſant, ſo ſpirited, ſo faſhionable, and make ſuch a noiſe in the world!—Why, 'tis the very thing I have been wiſhing for, ever ſince I thought of marriage.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I am happy to find you ſo readily approve of it.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
O dear! there is nothing gives a girl the air of conſequence an elopement does—To have one's name bandied about in all the newſpapers in the kingdom, with "We hear, that yeſterday morning, the only daughter of Lady Younglove eloped with a young gentleman of family, and great expectations—They were immediately purſued by the young Lady's relations, out in vain—The guardian powers of love and beauty had taken them under their
protection—Phaeton lent them his chariot, Cupid was the winged Charioteer, and Hymen on the oppoſite banks of the Tweed, with open arms, welcomed them into the dominions of joy and happineſs!"

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: My charming girl!—How your words animate me—I hope the event will prove equal to our moſt ſanguine expectations—But, let us not waſte the precious moments—Come, and—

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, not ſo haſty—Let me deſcend a little from my heroics to the level of common ſenſe—Stop here a few moments, while I juſt ſtep up ſtairs for ſome of my beſt cloaths.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: No, no, my dear, we ſhall have no occaſion for them.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ah, but I'm afraid we ſhall tho'—And if I can ſlip into my mamma's cloſet, I'll ſteal ſome of her jewels out.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Not for the world—You are the only jewel I wiſh to poſſeſs—Let us deal honourably, and truſt to her generoſity for the future.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Then I'm afraid you'll truſt to a broken reed.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: No matter, my love, we will put it to the teſt—I am ſenſible of the great hazard we both run by this precipitate ſtep, which nothing, but the fear of loſing you for ever, could urge me to—You, perhaps, have not conſidered it ſo ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Why no, truly, I ſeldom conſider about the matter—Reflection I know, will come time enough afterwards.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Then can you, my roſe-bud, in caſe your mamma is not reconciled to us, relinquiſh all hopes of a coach, with every other attendant on polite life, and be content to live in a cottage with love and me?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
I muſt own, that I ſhould like a coach prodigiouſly, but then I like you better—And if grandeur is only to be purchaſed at the expence of happineſs,
a ſig for it, and every other fine thing—Do you continue but to love me, and I ſhall be as happy as the day is long.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: My generous girl! whilſt I have life, it ſhall be my ſtudy ro repay ſuch obligations—Come, let us go down the back ſtairs, and proceed to Sedley's, where I have a chaiſe waiting for us.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh, undone! undone!—Here's your uncle, Sir Whiffling Trifle, and a French gentleman along with him, coming up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Zounds! how unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh, quite misfortunate indeed!

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O, dear! what will become of us?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Is there no place to hide me in?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: O none, Sir, except you creep up the chimney, and ſo on to the top of the next houſe.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Well, I am reſolved—Frippery, leave the room directly.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, O lud, O lud!

sp.speaker: Woodf. (taking hold of Flora)
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, my dear,—follow me, and fear nothing.

div.stage: Enter Sir WHIFFLING, ſpeaking to FINESSE.
div.p: So, Monſieur Fineſſe, you really think my Muſeum contains more curioſities than—Hey, Mr. Woodford! in the name of all that's wonderful, what brought you here?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: A deſign, Sir Whiffling, which your coming has unluckily interrupted, though not prevented—Let me beg of you therefore, to entertain Monſieur Fineſſe with the remainder of your invaluable curioſities, while I attend your niece down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed!—Hold, hold, Sir! you may go when, and where you pleaſe, but my niece ſhall not ſtir.

sp.speaker: Woodf. (pulling out a piſtol)
sp.p: You ſee, Sir Whiffling, all reſiſtance is in vain.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Help! murder! help!

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Not ſo loud, as you value your life.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: For pity's ſake, Monſieur, draw and aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Pardonnez moy, Monſieur, I beg to be excuſe.

sp.speaker: Woodf. (Drawing towards the door with Flora)
sp.p: Lookee, Sir Whiffling, if you offer to moleſt me before I'm down ſtairs, and out of doors, the conſequences may be fatal—Remember that caution as you regard your ſafety.

div.stage: After they have ſtood ſome time looking at each other.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Do you think they are down ſtairs yet?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: No, Monſieur, wait a leatle bit longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Draw your ſword, and ſee if they be gone.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: To oblige you, I vill draw my ſword, but, je vous demande pardon, I have more politeſſe dan to go before in your own houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Huſh!—I believe we may venture now—Come, follow me then.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui, Monſieur, I ſhall take de great care not to go firſt.

div.stage: Enter Miſs BLOOMER, and Mrs. FASHION.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: My dear Lady, I have impatiently expected you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: How does his Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Juſt alive, that's all.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Then there's no occaſion for my diſturbing him.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: The greateſt in the world—He cannot die in peace till he has ſeen you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I wiſh our interview was over—You'll be ſure to ſtay all the time in the room with me.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Certainly—Nay, don't heſitate but let me lead you to him.

div.stage: SCENE changes, diſcovers a room darkened. FLAMWELL lying on a couch.
Enter Mrs. FASHION, and Miſs BLOOMER.

sp.speaker: Faſh (ſoftly)
sp.p: My Lord!—My Lord!—'Tis all over—My Lord!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Oh!—diſturb me not—let me expire in quiet—'Tis not my charmer's voice.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Still raving on you.—My ſweet Lord, compoſe yourſelf—I have brought Miſs Bloomer to take a laſt farewell.

sp.speaker: Flam. (a little raiſing himſelf)
sp.p: I am very faint—Ah, Madam, would I had ſtrength to thank you for this favour!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Be compoſed, my Lord—I am heartily ſorry for your misfortune, and that I was the innocent occaſion of it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I bleſs the hour, ſince it has procured me this ſatisfaction—I am weak with the loſs of blood—Might I intreat you to come a little nearer—

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Do, my dear Miſs Bloomer, ſit down here—His Lordſhip cannot ſpeak loud.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I have but few moments to ſpare—On that table, Madam, lies my will, properly atteſted—In it you will find the reſpect I have entertained for you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, excuſe me, and give it to thoſe who better deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: By my faith, he will not, ſo no more words.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I have but one requeſt to make, and then—I die compoſed.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Name it, my Lord,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: That you might be legally mine, and—

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: My lord!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: And after my death, without interruption, quietly to enjoy my title as well as fortune.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I am greatly obliged to your Lordſhip, but give me leave poſitively, to decline both.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Nay, now, Miſs Bloomer, I really think you are very wrong—Conſider, what an advantage it will be to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I deſpiſe advantages obtained in ſuch a manner.

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Indeed, you are too delicate—It will be a public and honourable teſtimony of his love and gratitude.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I deſire no ſuch teſtimonies, and, if that was your deſign, you'll find you've loſt your aim.

sp.speaker: Faſh. (Stopping her)
sp.p: Can you refuſe ſuch a trifling, momentary ſatisfaction to a man who is juſt leaving the world?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Can you be ſo inhuman, to load a man juſt leaving the world, with ſuch a weight as matrimony?

sp.speaker: Faſh.
sp.p: Come, all this is feigned—You muſt and ſhall be Lady Flamwell—the Chaplain is waiting without—I'll call him in, and he'll ſoon run over the words—Here, Mr. Ty'em,—walk in, walk in!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Mrs. Faſhion!—Stay!—What do you mean by uſing me thus?—I'll leave your houſe inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Ty'em.
sp.p: Are the parties ready?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: No, Sir—Have a care what you are about—If you dare proceed a ſtep further in this affair, you ſhall be made a public example of.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: My gentle Lady, can you ſuffer me to die in deſpair?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: My ungentle Lord! I am not to be trick'd in this manner—Ceaſe your idle ſolicitations.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Not but with my life—Your cruelty has given me new vigor (Riſing from his couch) And thus I ſeize my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Hold off!—What! have I been deceiv'd!—enſnar'd!—'Tis plain—Villain!—who are you?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: A man, Madam, who is reſolved to make a proper uſe of this advantage—Come, Madam, you have no time for deliberation—Either this moment let me make you honourably mine, or—neceſſity will compel me to make uſe of force to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Monſter! I deteſt you, and deſpiſe your threats!—Dare not for your life, Sir, to bar my way.

sp.speaker: Ty'em.
sp.p: Verily, you are righteouſly joined together, and I am ready to affirm, that the ceremony is performed.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: How am I beſet!

sp.speaker: Flam. (taking hold of her)
sp.p: You muſt comply—There is no poſſibility of eſcaping.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Help! murder! help!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: 'Tis all in vain.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Help! help! for heaven's ſake!

div.stage: Door broke open—Enter SEDLEY, WOODFORD, CONSTABLE, and SERVANTS. They ſecure FLAMWELL and TY'EM.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Hold, miſcreants! or this moment is your laſt.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Look to the Lady, ſhe faints—

sp.speaker: Confr.
sp.p: Look to the gentleman here, firſt—He ſeems to be in the worſt condition.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p:
What a ſcene of horror!—Dear Woodford,
do you ſecure that wicked woman without, while I aſſiſt Miſs Bloomer.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I will, and as I ſhall take your advice in reſtoring Flora to her mother, will leave Mrs. Faſhion in the hands of theſe worthy gentlemen, and wait at your houſe for your return.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: O, Sedley! is it to you that I am indebted for this providential reſcue?—'Tis doubly, doubly welcome.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Madam, that I cannot return the compliment—Mr. Conſtable, conduct theſe villains to your own houſe, till they are properly examined.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—Come along, my lads, don't be ſo down-hearted—You are not ſo bad now as you will be, that's ſome comfort—The gallows, you know, never can come out of ſeaſon to you, and ſo, better late than never.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: O, my curſt fortune!—Yes, now I ſee I ſhall cut a diſtinguiſhing figure in the world!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: When we laſt parted, Miſs Bloomer, little did I expect we ſhould have met in ſuch a manner—Give me leave to aſk, what am I to judge from your appearance here?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: The truth—that I was innocently decoyed here, by the wicked woman who keeps this houſe.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Fain, fain would I believe ſo, did not other parts of your conduct contradict it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: My conduct, Sir, though faulty in this particular, is in every other reſpect irreproachable.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I ſhould be happy indeed, Madam, if you could prove it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Surprizing!—What right have you, Sir, to call my actions in queſtion?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: None, Madam, none—The buſy world has done it for you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Know, Sir, I rely on my own integrity, and deſpiſe what you or the world can ſay of me.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: It too plainly appears, Madam, that you have not the leaſt regard for either.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Good heavens! but I will be calm—I ſee your artifice, you poorly ſeek an excuſe for your own inconſtancy—The oaths, the vows, the ſighs you ſo long offered up to me, are now transferred to a more amiable, and deſerving object—Lady Younglove, Sir, has ſent me an invitation of the kindeſt nature—

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I know it, Madam—Too long have I dangled in the train of a Coquette, but I am at laſt convinced, that the levity of your conduct, forbids me ever to hope the leaſt happineſs, with a woman of your gaiety.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Burſt, burſt, ſwelling boſom, ere I give you vent. (aſide) O, Sir, you are convinced at laſt—'Tis very well, Sir,—I am ſatisfied—perfectly ſatisfied—Then you give me up for ever.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: For ever, Madam, by heaven!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Cruel, ungenerous, Sedley!—What have I done to deſerve this inſult?—eſpecially from you, who of all men, I am leaſt able to bear it from.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Tears! my heart can hold no longer—Madam, Miſs Bloomer!—Heaven is my witneſs, I bleed to wound you thus—I love you! I adore you!—Had I millions they ſhould be yours—But, what can I ſay?—Thus circumſtanced, I am compelled, dear as I love, to bid you eternally farewell—Yet, though I am wretched, compleatly wretched, may the guardian powers of love and innocence, wait on your footſteps, ſhadow you with their wings, and conduct you to that happineſs you have deprived me of.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p:
Stay, raſh man, ſtay—My pride forbids
me to ſtoop to a vindication—Yet, my weakneſs confeſſes, that had it not been for your preſent behaviour, I ſhould have preferred you before all the men I ever ſaw—'Till this moment I knew not half the power you had over me—Yes, cruel Sedley, enjoy that triumph, but at the ſame time know, I will, if poſſible, tear your image from my breaſt, and bury myſelf where I may never hear your name mentioned.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Hold, my charming angel!—By heaven you ſhall not go—Thus on my knees (Kneeling) let me intreat for pardon—Forgive the man, who doats on you to diſtraction, who lives but in your ſmiles—Abhorred be my tongue for thus wantonly wounding your ſenſibility, and uttering what my heart diſclaims.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed!—And, are you really not engaged to Lady Younglove?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: By all the powers of love, I am not, nor ever will be—'Twas all an artifice, to ſerve my friend, and try the ſtrength of your affection—If you refuſe my hand, never ſhall it be the lifeleſs property of another.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Generous man! I am not worthy of you!—No, Sedley, virtues like yours deſerve infinitely more than I am able to beſtow.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Say not ſo, my beauteous girl!—You muſt, you ſhall be mine—My happineſs is centered in you—Bleſt be the fortunate accident that thus luckily revealed I was not indifferent to you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p:
And doubly bleſt let it be, ſince it has opened my eyes, and ſhewn me the glaring impropriety of my former conduct—What a dreadful precipice have I eſcaped!—How have I—But, my future life beſt ſhall ſpeak my ſenſe of the paſt—Here let me ſeriouſly renounce all former follies—Never from this hour, will I be guilty of them—You have at laſt effectually compleated the arduous
taſk you ſo long purſued—REFORMED A COQUETTE—And now, if you dare—take her for your pains.

sp.speaker: Sedley. (Embracing her)
sp.p: O tranſport inexprſſible!—Am I at laſt rewarded!

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Hey-day! may I believe my eyes!—Here's a change indeed!—Embraching!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: O, my dear girl! I am glad you are come.

sp.speaker: Miſs Belg.
sp.p: Really, ſo am I.—Your humble ſervant, Mr. Proteus, I am pleaſed to find you in ſuch ſpirits—Not an hour ago, you was the reſolute determined hero—No, no, Madam, I can love without being blind.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: True, Madam, and without being entirely ſo; where could I ſix, but on ſo deſerving an object? You ſeem ſurprized: let us adjourn to Lady Younglove's, and in our way thither, I'll let you into my whole deſign.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Here, take my hand—My heart has not been ſo much at eaſe a long time—And, if girls were but wiſe enough to conſult their own happineſs, inſtead of their triſling with fools and coxcombs, they would ſeek for it where it can only be found—In the arms of men of ſenſe, and virtue.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: UPON my word, Miſs, this is the moſt oddeſt affair I was ever extricated in during the whole current of my life—After getting ſo artificially off as you did, for Mr. Sedley to diſſuade your lovyer to return you to your mamma again, inſtead of flouriſhing away to Scotland without redemption—Well! I own its above my compacity to find out.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ay, or mine either—I'm ſure, I never looked ſo fooliſh in all my life, as when I found we were not to be married.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: And well you might, Miſs, to have all your ſchemes confiſticated in ſuch a manner.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: And then, Frippery, to be diſappointed of ſuch a delightful jaunt, and expoſed to the ridicule of all one's acquaintance—'Tis, enough to make me cry my eyes out.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ay, my dear, ſo it is—And, pray, what end did he impoſe by this wiſe ſcheme?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Why, as by ſuch a precipitate ſtep we ſhould entirely forfeit the favour of his uncle, and my mamma, without the leaſt chance of recovery, he perſuaded Woodford to wait the iſſue of a ſcheme which he is going to execute immediately—For my part, if it does ſucceed, I ſhall loſe half the pleaſure I expected in being married in Scotland.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p:
You are right, Miſs, and ſpeak the ſenſations of moſt of the girls who go there—Why, I might have been married three years ago to Mr. Scraper, Lord Supple's footman, but that we could not raiſe
money enough between us to get there, and I was determined never to follow the vulgar faſhion, of being aſked in church.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: So, my pretty runaway Miſs! I have you ſafe once more, thanks to Mr. Sedley, and ſhall take care to keep you ſo.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Perhaps you may be miſtaken (aſide) It is mighty well, mamma, but you would not like to be ſerved ſo yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Go, huſſey, you are a pert ſpoiled girl—Now, Frippery, after this laſt generous act of Mr. Sedley's, I think, I can't have the leaſt doubt of his ſincerity, truth, and tenderneſs.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Doubt, Madam! it would be downright fidelity even to inſpect him of ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: How tediouſly the lazy minutes drawl, to a heart impatient of its bliſs like mine!—Frippery, do you think I am elegantly enough dreſſed for my bridal day?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Elegant, my Lady!—Why, you are the very moral of gentility—Your new cork-rump becomes you mightily—And Mr. Friz, the hair-dreſſer, 〈…〉 your head is now at leaſt half a foot higher 〈◊〉 the handſome Ducheſs's.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I am glad of it—O, the dear, ſweet 〈◊〉 !—He promiſed to be here about this time—I 〈◊〉 he was come—My patience is almoſt exhauſted, 〈◊〉 I tremble left any accident ſhould rob me of my expected happineſs.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: If ſhe ſhould be diſappointed now.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I warrant your Ladyſhip need not fear—No, no, Mr. Sedley is too much of a gentleman to refuſe you any thing.

div.stage: Enter SEDLEY, Captain HELM, Miſs BLOOMER, WOODFORD, and SWAB.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: My beauteous widow!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: My long expected love!

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I wiſh my mamma would not be quite ſo fond before company.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: My dear Lady, I have been obliged to treſpaſs on your patience, in order to bring theſe witneſſes of my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, widow, we have crowded all the ſail we could to be in at the firſt broadſide, and now, as we all ſeem in the line, ſuppoſe we hoiſt the ſignal for engaging?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: With all my heart, Captain, the ſooner, the better.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Bravely ſpoken, and I'll anſwer, that you'll not be the firſt to cry out quarter.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, Miſs Bloomer! I am happy to ſee you—My dear, this is an unexpected favour—Well, now, after your known partiality for Sedley, can you forgive his infidelity to you?—I proteſt it gives me pain to rob you of ſuch a ſweet man.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip is too good—I ſhould be vain indeed, were I to pretend to diſpute a heart with one of your Ladyſhip's age and experience.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! very pleaſant—And yet, I really wonder, what the men can ſee in me ſo to follow and admire—Eſpecially, when they ſacrifice ſuch youth and beauty—But, I hope no bad conſequences will follow your diſappointment—No hanging, or drowning—O lud! I poſitively will give up all thoughts of him, ſooner than be the death of any perſon.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: What a malicious devil. (aſide) I hope, Madam, I have now removed every ſhadow of doubt which your Ladyſhip might have entertained of my ſincerity.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p:
Entirely, Sir, entirely—And, in order to convince the world of my diſintereſted love for ſo deſerving an object—Previous to the ceremony, which is to make me happy for ever—there
is a deed of gift— (Preſenting it to Sedley)—properly atteſted, of half my fortune at preſent, and, the other half at my death.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: My dear Lady, what can I ſay to ſuch unbounded, ſuch unmerited proofs of your goodneſs?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Say! zounds, man, ſay nothing—The widow had rather be thanked in deed than in word.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am afraid, Captain, it is not in my power to pleaſe the Lady either way.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O fie, Mr. Sedley, don't think ſo—I aſſure you I am not the unreaſonable woman you take me for.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am glad of it, Madam, as I muſt ſpeedily put you to the trial.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I think, Sir, I can ſtand any trial you'll pleaſe to make.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I wiſh we may find it ſo, Madam—By your miſplaced, and with juſtice I may ſay, ridiculous inclination, my Lady, for I cannot call it love, you have been ſo far blindly infatuated, as to make me ſole maſter of your fortune without reſerve—

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: How!—Am I awake?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Faith, I believe not—But, there ſeems a ſtorm riſing that will quickly call all hands to work.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well! I declare this is charming!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am above making an improper uſe of ſuch an advantage—I deſigned at firſt, but to ſerve my friend, and now my end is fully anſwered—Give me leave therefore, in the preſence of this good company, to reſtore theſe writings to their juſt owner.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhall faint! this is too much, too much to bear!

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Poor mamma! So, it is indeed, to loſe both money and huſband—Sir, I have not words to thank you as I ought.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Am I betrayed then!—You baſe deluder! villain!

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I hope your Ladyſhip will forgive his infidelity to you—I proteſt it gives me pain to rob you of ſuch a ſweet man.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Confuſion! are all my raviſhing dreams of happineſs come to this!—Oh, the inconſtancy of mankind! there's neither love, faith, truth, or honour amongſt them.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: But, I hope, no bad conſquences will follow your diſappointment—No hanging, or drowning—O lud! I poſitively will give up all thoughts of him, ſooner than be the death of any perſon.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Come, my Lady, forgive this innocent artifice, and look upon me as your beſt friend—You might have fallen a dupe to ſome deſigning villain—who, taking advantage of your weakneſs, would have ruined your family, and entailed perpetual miſery on yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: So! we are all run on a lee ſhore, here!—Why, widow, you have kept a deviliſh bad reckoning—But I thought how it would be—As for your generoſity, Mr. Sedley, in favour of my little cockboat, why, I heartily thank you—And, as ſoon as the parſon can tip us a cocket, we'll ſteer away for matrimony harbour, directly.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I'm afraid, Captain, wind and tide are ſo much againſt you, that you'll hardly be able to reach the port this trip.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: How's this!—Do you refuſe to take convoy too?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: No, provided I chuſe my confort—I'm ſure, if I kept company with you, I ſhould ſoon be obliged to take you in tow.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Whew! (whiſtling) Here's a freſh gale ſprung up!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I think, Captain, you have kept a bad reckoning.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
And now, Woodford, thanks to Mr. Sedley's
generoſity, I have it in my power to manifeſt my love—Here, take my hand, my fortune's more than ſufficient to enable us to live happily, though not ſplendidly—But, were it not, be aſſured, I would chearfully prefer poverty and a cottage, with the object of my choice, before riches and the moſt ſplendid palace with the man I diſlike.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Right, Madam, the temple of Hymen was reared by virtue, and only occaſionally embelliſhed by Plutus.—Captain, I am ſure, if you ſeriouſly conſider every thing, you will ſoon be of the young Lady's mind.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: May-hap not, for when I am reſolved on doing any thing, I never think about the matter.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Dear uncle, make my happineſs complete by reſtoring me to your favour—Recollect what a cruel conſtraint you were putting upon both our inclinations.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: And, you young dog, do you recollect what a cruel conſtraint you are putting upon mine?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I know, Captain, you are a noble-ſpirited, worthy-hearted Briton—Only reflect, with ſuch a great diſparity of years and temper, what a ridiculous figure you muſt make united to ſo blooming a girl.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ay, for all the world, like David and Abiſhag, in our old tapeſtry hangings.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Come, be generous, and act like yourſelf—Fill up the marriage ſettlements with your nephew's name, inſtead of your own, and receive the thanks, nay, the bleſſings of the young couple, for ſo laudable an act.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Upon my knees, uncle, let me beg—

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Riſe, you land ſpaniel—When did you ever ſee a ſeaman in ſuch a poſture?—Had it been for a brother tar, why, I ſhould not have held council about it.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Well! it is ſome comfort, to find others in the ſame ſituation with myſelf.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: So! after rigging myſelf out for a cruize to the unknown iſlands, my orders are countermanded, I am to be dock'd, and laid up for life, as unfit for ſervice.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Why, an pleaſe your honour, I do think your works are too much damaged, to venture out to ſea again—You'd certainly founder in the firſt ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Do you think ſo, Swab?—Then let us tack about, and alter our courſe—Come hither, nephew, I forgive you what's paſt—You ſhall go maſter in my ſtead, and here are bills of freight and lading for the voyage—But, harkee, as you are a young ſeaman, take my advice—Don't crowd too much ſail, or you'll be apt to overſet.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Never fear, uncle, I'll ſteer by your direction—your goodneſs to me on this occaſion—

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No fair-weather ſpeeches, but mind your buſineſs—And, d'ye hear, boy, by way of encouragement to ſerve his Majeſty, you ſhall have a thouſand pounds bounty money for every young volunteer you produce, as ſoon as ever they are able to cry, Huzza! King George and his navy for ever—Ay, damme! tho' you ſhould have above the royal dozen!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: There ſpoke the true ſpirit of a Britiſh ſeaman.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: What ſay you. Widow?—As we both have been a couple of ridiculous old fools, to make amends, will you join with me, and do the ſame?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Do the ſame, Captain?—I did not rightly underſtand you—You have not, ſurely, any notion of paying your addreſſes to me?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: To you!—Avaſt there, ſheer off——No, ſooner than be tack'd to ſuch a ſpit-fire, I'd turn a gun into my powder-room, and blow myſelf up.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: A monſter!—A ſavage bear!—Fit only for Greenland!

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Well! a Greenland bear is better than a Lapland witch, at any time.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Come along, Frippery—The men have neither eyes, ears, or underſtanding!

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let her have ſea-room enough, or ſhe'll run foul of ſome of you.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honour, ſince you are ſharing the prize-money, I hope you'll not be angry if I put in my claim?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: What wind blows now?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: A fair gale, your honour; if I can but preſs yon painter tender into ſervice.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Oh, are you in that quarter?—Have you a mind to deſert your commander in diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: No, your honour, never while I have life—, ſhe ſeems a neat tight-ſailing thing, and her upper works are in ſuch nice order, that I ſhould like, of all things, to go maſter.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: But, hearkee, have you hail'd her yet, to know whether ſhe'd chuſe to take you on board?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Why, no, your honour; I'm too good a ſeaman to launch out on ſo long a cruize without my commander's leave.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Well, then, Swab, if that's the caſe, after her directly, and bring her too as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I warrant your honour; to give a good account of her—He muſt ſtand many a hard broadſide that takes her from me.

div.stage: Enter Miſs BELCROVE, Sir WHIFLING, and SPANGLE.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hey day! here's a Venetian galley, and a whole ſquadron of Turkiſh cruizers in full chace of her.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bel.
sp.p: True, Captain, I have been oblig'd to ran for it, and glad to find this harbour open.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Say you ſo, then let me ſtand in—I'll ſoon make them tack about, and ſheer off.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bel.
sp.p: No occaſion, Captain, I'll ſtand my ground now, and face them—Well, good folks, I ſee by thoſe ſmiles that are ſeated on your countenances, that every thing is happily ſettled—I give you joy—I met theſe gentlemen in my way hither, they would not believe me, ſo are come to receive their diſmiſſion from your own lips.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Is this true, my dear girl, that you have the inhumanity to be the death of all my hopes?

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: And can you, Miſs Bloomer, behold my ſufferings without a touch of pity?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: The time has been, gentlemen, when I could have play'd on your follies, and encouraged them with the higheſt pleaſure—At preſent, I am diſpoſed to be more ſerious—Therefore, in a word, I beg I may not be honoured with your addreſſes more, as you may reſt aſſured, that I never will give you, or any others, the leaſt encouragement.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: And this, my dear, is your poſitive reſolution?

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Poſitive.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, my dear, I am ſorry for your taſte—But to ſhew you how faſhionably eaſy I am, under my diſappointment—May elegance renounce me, if I ever aſk you again—So, ladies and gentlement, wiſhing you all happineſs, I have the honour, ſans ceremonie, to remain, till my lateſt moments, your moſt devoted humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—As to you, Sir Whifling, I hope your philoſophy will teach you to bear this event with equal reſignation.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O, I'll anſwer for my uncle——Give him another antedeluvian cockle-ſhell, and he'll renounce the ſex for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Not ſo pert, Miſs—Madam, your frankneſs charms me—I begin to perceive that I deſerve ridicule for the folly of my purſuits—But, to ſhew you, that, tho' I am old, I am not incorrigible, I'll from this moment bid adieu to all thoughts of love, and devote the remainder of my life to more noble ſtudies than either brickbats, cinders, or mutilated ſtatues.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: Now, Belgrove, are not theſe genuine fruits of reformation?

div.stage: Enter FINESSE. [On ſeeing Sedley and Miſs Bloomer, attempts to retire]

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Ha! Monſieur Fineſſe, come back—Why in ſuch a hurry?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Je demande pardon for my intruſion—You be upon de private buſineſs—Je revendrai demain, I'll come again to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sedley. (ſtopping him)
sp.p: No, Sir, the preſent time will do better—Hearkee, villain! what motive cou'd induce you to deſtroy my peace, by your infamous miſrepreſentations of Miſs Bloomer?—No evaſion, wretch! (drawing) or this moment ſhall be your laſt.

sp.speaker: Fin. (kneeling)
sp.p: O dear Sir! prenez garde!—Conſider how ſoon you may frighten a pauvre Frenchman out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bloom.
sp.p: What, my admirer, Monſieur Fineſſe, is it to you I am ſo much indebted?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ah, Madame! have pitie!—I confeſſe, I have been von grand rogue—But, je vous en ſupplie—I beſeech you to forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Riſe!—A moment's reflection ſhews me that you are a wretch beneath my reſentment.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I'l eſt vrai—It is true. indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hearkee, ſuppoſe we tar and feather him, and then ſend him home to his own country, to parlez vous with his relations.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: By no means, Captain—But, hence from my ſight, let me never ſee you more.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Vous me faites trop d' honneur—You do me too much honour.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: The Frenchman, of character and probity, I admire and eſteem—Virtue is not confin'd to clime or complexion, its radient emanations illumine every nation—Yet ſtill, I would not faſhionably encourage the reſuſe of foreign countries, while native merit lies buried in oblivion.

sp.speaker: Miſs Bel.
sp.p: So, Captain, you and I ſeem the only diſconſolate, unprovided creatures in the whole group—We certainly ſhould make a match of it, to complete the evening's entertainment.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No, no, fair Lady, you have ſome other land in view—As for me—But, no more of what's paſt—Let us enjoy the preſent moments.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: And look forward, uncle, to thoſe ſcenes of bliſs which open to our view.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: True, Boy, and as this ſeems but a bad harbour to anchor long in, let us all ſteer away for my cabin, where you ſhall have the beſt cheer an old bachelor can give, and as hearty a welcome as the braveſt ſailor in the navy.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: We accept your offer, Captain, happy in having our adventures brought to ſo agreeable a concluſion—I only beg leave to remark—That though our follies and vices juſtly deſerve the comic laſh—Yet, when, inſtead of perſevering, we nobly acknowledge our errors, and amend—Satire then loſes her ſting, our foibles turn to virtues, and, the moſt permanent felicity ariſes from THE MISTAKES OF THE HEART.
